metadata.background_info:
Related Questions on Metaculus:
If there's a nuclear conflict involving >100 detonations, will that cause >1 billion fatalities within 10 years?
If there's a nuclear conflict involving >100 detonations, will that cause >1 million fatalities within 1 month?
If there's a nuclear conflict involving >1000 detonations, will humanity be extinct within 50 years?
If there's a nuclear conflict involving >1000 detonations, will humanity's population be <400 million 50 years later?
Will the first nuclear conflict involving >100 detonations cause >100m fatalities within 1 month of the final detonation?
Decisions about how much to prioritize nuclear risk reduction and how best to reduce nuclear risk should be guided in part by our best guesses about:
how many deaths would occur given a large-scale nuclear exchange
what proportion of those deaths would occur fairly soon after the detonations (e.g., from the initial blast and fires) rather than later on (e.g., from fallout or nuclear winter effects)
For example, this is relevant to the existential risk posed by nuclear weapons and the value of investing in research and development on "resilient food".
See here, and the sources linked to from there, for previous discussion of these sorts of questions and why they matter.

Q.title: Will we detect a message originating from Luyten's Star before 2046?
Q.body:
Resolution Criteria
This question will resolve as positive if a signal of unambiguously intelligent and extraterrestrial origin originating from Luyten's Star is detected on or near Earth on or before December 31, 2045

metadata.background_info:
In October 2017, Messaging Extraterrestrial Intelligence International (METI) transmitted a signal into space designed to let other civilizations know we're here.
The message, transmitted to a red dwarf star 12 light-years from Earth and contains information on human understanding of science, math and time.
In March 2017, a planet three times the mass of Earth within the habitable zone was discovered orbiting the star. If there's anyone on that planet who receives the message, their reply could arrive as early as 2042.

reasons: The potential for a nuclear conflict involving over 1,000 detonations leading to massive global fatalities is a catastrophic event that would likely disrupt or destroy much of human civilization, including technological and scientific infrastructure. This would severely impact the capacity for scientific research and observation, including the search for extraterrestrial intelligence.

In the event of such a devastating nuclear conflict, priorities would shift significantly towards survival and rebuilding, likely deprioritizing projects like SETI (Search for Extraterrestrial Intelligence).
The detection of a message from Luyten's Star, while significant, would likely be overshadowed or rendered impractical in a world dealing with the aftermath of a nuclear apocalypse.
relevance.conclusion: Considering the logical combination of these two questions is relevant as the occurrence of a large-scale nuclear conflict could directly impact the feasibility and priority of detecting extraterrestrial messages.

P.title: If there is at least one nuclear detonation by 2030, in which countries will there be at least one fatality? (India)
P.body:
Resolution Criteria
This group is conditional on at least 1 offensive nuclear detonation occuring at any time between January 1, 2021 and January 1, 2030. If no such detonation occurs anywhere on Earth in this period, all sub-questions below will resolve as Ambiguous.
If there is at least one offensive nuclear detonation in this time period, the following sub-questions will resolve as Yes if there is at least 1 fatality from any nuclear detonation occuring in that country (or regions), at any point between January 1, 2021 to January 1, 2030. If there is no such fatality, the sub-question will resolve as No. If the only nuclear detonations in this period occur outside of all of the following areas (for example, they occur in international waters, or a region(s) not listed below), all options below will resolve as No.
The fatality must be caused by the immediate effects of the detonation; fatalities caused by eg. fallout, rioting, or climate effects will be excluded from resolution.
For this question, an "offensive nuclear detonation" includes deliberate, inadvertent, or accidental/unauthorised nuclear detonations of by state or nonstate actors, but doesn't include detonations for testing purposes or peaceful nuclear explosions (even if such detonations cause substantial damage).
Fine Print
Test detonations and peaceful nuclear explosions are defined as detonations which are claimed as being a test or a peaceful nuclear explosion by an official government communication within 30 days of the event, without this being disputed by reliable media, state reports, or multinational reports. Final determination of whether a detonation is a test/peaceful detonation is at the sole discretion of Metaculus Admins.

A detonation will be considered "within" a given country if it occurs less than 20 kilometers above the land or sea level in that country's land territory, internal waters, or within 10 kilometers of their coastline.

Q.title: Will a non-test nuclear detonation by a non-state actor cause at least one fatality by 2030?
Q.body:
Resolution Criteria
A nuclear detonation by a non-state actor could potentially have dire consequences either directly or via triggering other harmful actions by other actors. Non-state actors have never yet detonated nuclear weapons, but there are conceivable scenarios in which they could:
The majority of nuclear security experts identify two primary scenarios involving nuclear weapons and non-state actors. The first scenario involves the acquisition of a nuclear device from the existing arsenals of nuclear-armed States by terrorists or other non-state actors. The second scenario envisions the construction of a crude nuclear bomb by non-state actors using special nuclear materials—highly enriched uranium (HEU) or plutonium (Pu). The actualization of each of these scenarios would be very difficult, and the probability of a successful theft and detonation of an actual nuclear weapon or manufacturing of an improvised device by non-state actors is considered to be low. Yet, this probability is not zero.
Will a nuclear detonation by a non-state actor causes at least one fatality by 2030?
This question will resolve as Yes if, before January 1, 2030, a nuclear detonation by a non-state actor causes at least one fatality in any country or area globally.
The fatality must be caused by the immediate effects of the detonation, so a fatality caused by things like fallout, rioting, or climate effects will not count towards a positive resolution.
Resolution criteria will be gathered from reliable news sources or from direct government or multi-national reports such as from the UN.
Neither detonations for testing purposes nor peaceful nuclear explosions will count towards question resolution, even if such detonations cause substantial damage.
Test detonations and peaceful nuclear explosions are defined as detonations which are claimed as being a test or a peaceful nuclear explosion by an official government communication within 30 days of the event, without this being disputed by reliable media, state reports, or multinational reports. If information is unclear, then resolution will be left up to the resolution council or Metaculus admins.

P_and_Q.title: Will there be at least one fatality in India from an offensive nuclear detonation by 2030, and will a non-test nuclear detonation by a non-state actor cause at least one fatality globally by 2030?
P_and_Q.body:
Resolution Criteria for both sub-questions:

1. For the first part regarding India: This resolves YES if there is at least one offensive nuclear detonation anywhere between January 1, 2021, and January 1, 2030, and at least one fatality occurs in India from any such detonation. The fatality must be caused by the immediate effects of the detonation. An "offensive nuclear detonation" includes deliberate, inadvertent, or accidental/unauthorised nuclear detonations by state or nonstate actors, excluding detonations for testing purposes or peaceful nuclear explosions. A detonation will be considered "within" India if it occurs less than 20 kilometers above the land or sea level in India's land territory, internal waters, or within 10 kilometers of their coastline.

2. For the second part regarding a non-state actor globally: This resolves YES if, before January 1, 2030, a nuclear detonation by a non-state actor causes at least one fatality anywhere globally. The fatality must be caused by the immediate effects of the detonation. Neither detonations for testing purposes nor peaceful nuclear explosions will count towards question resolution.

Both parts must resolve YES for the overall question to resolve as YES. If either part resolves NO, the overall question resolves as NO.

Q_and_P.title: Will a non-test nuclear detonation by a non-state actor cause at least one fatality by 2030 AND will there be at least one fatality in India from any offensive nuclear detonation by 2030?
Q_and_P.body: Resolves YES if both of the following occur: a.) A nuclear detonation by a non-state actor causes at least one fatality by 2030, where the fatality must be caused by the immediate effects of the detonation, excluding fatalities caused by fallout, rioting, or climate effects. This excludes detonations for testing purposes or peaceful nuclear explosions. b.) There is at least one fatality in India from any offensive nuclear detonation occurring between January 1, 2021, and January 1, 2030, where the fatality must be caused by the immediate effects of the detonation, excluding fatalities caused by fallout, rioting, or climate effects. This also excludes detonations for testing purposes or peaceful nuclear explosions. Resolves NO otherwise. Resolution criteria will be gathered from reliable news sources or from direct government or multi-national reports such as from the UN. If no offensive nuclear detonation occurs anywhere on Earth in this period, the question will resolve as NO.

P.title: Will alien technosignatures be detected before 2050?
P.body:
Resolution Criteria
This question will resolve as Yes if a competent and credible authority on astronomy and or space exploration (such as NASA, ESA, ROSCOSMOS, CNSA, JAXA, SETI or similar) announces that, on the balance of probabilities (i.e. more than 50% likely), technosignatures of non-human origin have been discovered before January 1, 2050. This announcement qualifies only if it is made after a year waiting period following the initial announcement of the detection, unless the space agencies of the US, Russia, China and Europe all agree that the finding is genuine. Evidence of biosignatures alone will not be directly relevant to the resolution of this question.
By 'non-human origin,' this question refers to technosignatures that are not the result of human activity, or of the activity of any technology or 'lifeform' created by humans, including any artificial intelligence system or biological organism

metadata.background_info:
Technosignatures are any measurable property or effect that provide scientific evidence of past or present technology, and are key to the search for extraterrestrial intelligence.
Technosignatures include (but are not limited to) evidence of electromagnetic transmissions of information, artificial heat and light, astroengineering projects (Dyson spheres and swarms, Matrioshka brains, stellar engines etc), asteroid or other space mining projects, and spacecraft.

Q.title: Will humans have a sustainable off-world presence by 2100?
Q.body:
Resolution Criteria
This question will resolve as Yes if, at any point before January 1, 2100, there is a settlement(s) off-Earth with over 2,000 5+ year residents that are self-sufficient in production of energy and foodstuffs

metadata.background_info:
In the 1970s Gerard K. O’Neill wrote and published his seminal work, The High Frontier. In it O’Neill first paints a picture of habitats floating in space, with people living on the insides of cylinders kilometres long, and then describes how one could accomplish this from an engineering perspective with the Space Shuttle, then still in the planning stages.
The Shuttle turned out to be more expensive and less reusable than it was optimistically lauded to be, but it stands to reason: where are the space settlements? Certainly not in low earth orbit.
But they don’t have to be. What once pushed the envelope of the technically feasible is now well established as doable. The Mir was an initially Soviet, later Russian space station from 1986–1996, crewed for almost ten years. The International Space Station took 12 years to construct and has been crewed since November 2000. By the time it too will be decomissioned almost a whole generation will have passed since the first crew boarded it.
ESA wants to build a moon village, while NASA (and Elon Musk) aim for Mars.

reasons: The detection of alien technosignatures could significantly impact the motivation and funding for space exploration, potentially accelerating the establishment of a sustainable off-world presence.
The discovery of non-human technosignatures might lead to increased collaboration among nations and private entities in space, which could facilitate the development of off-world settlements.

Knowing that there are other technologically advanced civilizations could shift public and political priorities towards space exploration and habitation, influencing the timeline for achieving a sustainable off-world presence.
relevance.conclusion: Considering the logical combination of these questions is relevant as the detection of alien technosignatures could directly influence the efforts and priorities in establishing a sustainable human presence off-world.

P.title: Will synthetic biological weapons infect 100 people by 2030?
P.body:
Resolution Criteria
This question will resolve as Yes if a credible medical source announces at least 100 people are confirmed "infected" by one or more confirmed synthetic "biological weapon"s and that this has occured before 2030. The consequences of infection may or may not be immediately harmful. An agent can even be latent, or cause a delayed onset of disease, as long as the agent is still present and functional 24 hrs after infection (as opposed to being destroyed by the immune system). But if it causes some definite, confirmed harmful effect, and then self-destructs before 24 hrs have passed, that would still count. The infection can result from a terrorist attack, attack on enemy military personnel, an experiment, accident, with the infected persons' consent, or from any other cause

Q.title: Will there be recurring virus-driven lockdowns during the period 2030-2050?
Q.body:
Resolution Criteria
Lockdowns are said to be "recurring" during the period 2030-2050 if any of the following become true during that time period,
At least three separate virus species, according to the ICTV classification of viruses, are reported to have triggered at least three separate global lockdown events, defined as events in which at least 50% of the world population simultaneously live under stay-at-home orders for some period of time.
During at least five separate incidents, it is not possible to see an in-person Broadway Show in New York City due to stay-at-home orders in New York City as a result of a viral event. An incident is said to be separate if Broadway theaters lifted restrictions for some time, before being mandated again.
The Summer Olympic Games OR Winter Olympic Games are rescheduled at least three times as a result of viral related events.
Fine Print
Disputes related to question wording will be determined using admin discretion.

The infection can result from a terrorist attack, attack on enemy military personnel, an experiment, accident, with the infected persons' consent, or from any other cause.

Resolution Criteria for recurring virus-driven lockdowns: Lockdowns are said to be "recurring" during the period 2030-2050 if any of the following become true during that time period,
At least three separate virus species, according to the ICTV classification of viruses, are reported to have triggered at least three separate global lockdown events, defined as events in which at least 50% of the world population simultaneously live under stay-at-home orders for some period of time.
During at least five separate incidents, it is not possible to see an in-person Broadway Show in New York City due to stay-at-home orders in New York City as a result of a viral event. An incident is said to be separate if Broadway theaters lifted restrictions for some time, before being mandated again.
The Summer Olympic Games OR Winter Olympic Games are rescheduled at least three times as a result of viral related events.

Fine Print
Disputes related to question wording will be determined using admin discretion.

Q_and_P.title: Will there be recurring virus-driven lockdowns during 2030-2050 AND will synthetic biological weapons infect 100 people by 2030?
Q_and_P.body:
Resolves YES if both of the following occur: 
1. Recurring virus-driven lockdowns during the period 2030-2050, defined as any of the following: 
a) At least three separate virus species, according to the ICTV classification of viruses, trigger at least three separate global lockdown events, where at least 50% of the world population simultaneously live under stay-at-home orders for some period. 
b) At least five separate incidents where it is not possible to see an in-person Broadway Show in New York City due to stay-at-home orders in New York City as a result of a viral event, with Broadway theaters having lifted restrictions between incidents. 
c) The Summer Olympic Games OR Winter Olympic Games are rescheduled at least three times due to viral related events. 
2. At least 100 people are confirmed "infected" by one or more confirmed synthetic "biological weapon"s before 2030, as announced by a credible medical source. The infection can result from various causes including terrorist attacks, attacks on enemy military personnel, experiments, accidents, or with the infected persons' consent. The agent must be present and functional 24 hrs after infection, even if it causes a delayed onset of disease or is latent. 
Resolves NO otherwise.

P.title: Will synthetic biological weapons infect 100 people by 2030?
P.body:
Resolution Criteria
This question will resolve as Yes if a credible medical source announces at least 100 people are confirmed "infected" by one or more confirmed synthetic "biological weapon"s and that this has occured before 2030. The consequences of infection may or may not be immediately harmful. An agent can even be latent, or cause a delayed onset of disease, as long as the agent is still present and functional 24 hrs after infection (as opposed to being destroyed by the immune system). But if it causes some definite, confirmed harmful effect, and then self-destructs before 24 hrs have passed, that would still count. The infection can result from a terrorist attack, attack on enemy military personnel, an experiment, accident, with the infected persons' consent, or from any other cause

metadata.background_info:
A synthetic biological weapon is a 'living' agent capable of infecting, harming, and/or killing a target host. For the purposes of this question, we focus on human hosts, exclude weapons that consist only of toxins, even if their source is biological: synthetic or otherwise. Nor does it include something like a genetically engineered mosquito carrying natural unmodified malaria. 'Living' means it must either be self-reproducing, like a bacteria or parasite, or like a virus, capable of hijacking a host cell to produce new copies of itself. A synthetic biological agent may be a 'natural' disease causing organism that has at least been genetically engineered (and not merely selectively bred); an entirely new kind of organism, virus, or similar created from scratch; or anything in between those extremes.
If the agent is based on an existing disease causing organism, there must be confirmation that the symptoms of infection by the disease causing agent(s) are confirmed by a credible medical source to be different than those of the original, or alternatively that the infectious 'behavior', or capabilities of the agent are confirmed different than the original. This is to exclude infections that are medically indistuingishable from the natural version, which might make cases too difficult to verify.
The consequences of infection must be undesireable - ie, not something that could concievably be offered as a product for improving the health of a customer, to improve athletic or cognitive abilities, for recreational use, or any other purpose desireable to those infected. It must be confirmed to be at least capable of adversely impacting the victims' physical or mental health, making them smell in a way that attracts trained dogs, causing them to develop an addiction to some brand of fast food, or some other undesireable effect.

Q.title: Will there be recurring virus-driven lockdowns during the period 2030-2050?
Q.body:
Resolution Criteria
Lockdowns are said to be "recurring" during the period 2030-2050 if any of the following become true during that time period,
At least three separate virus species, according to the ICTV classification of viruses, are reported to have triggered at least three separate global lockdown events, defined as events in which at least 50% of the world population simultaneously live under stay-at-home orders for some period of time.
During at least five separate incidents, it is not possible to see an in-person Broadway Show in New York City due to stay-at-home orders in New York City as a result of a viral event. An incident is said to be separate if Broadway theaters lifted restrictions for some time, before being mandated again.
The Summer Olympic Games OR Winter Olympic Games are rescheduled at least three times as a result of viral related events.
Fine Print
Disputes related to question wording will be determined using admin discretion.

metadata.background_info:
From Wikipedia,
A lockdown is a restriction policy for people or community to stay where they are, usually due to specific risks to themselves or to others if they can move and interact freely. The term "stay-at-home" or "shelter-in-place" is often used for lockdowns that affect an area, rather than specific locations. [...]
During the COVID-19 pandemic, the term lockdown was used for actions related to mass quarantines or stay-at-home orders. The first lockdown during the pandemic was implemented in Wuhan on January 23, 2020. By early April 2020, 3.9 billion people worldwide were under some form of lockdown—more than half the world's population. By late April, around 300 million people were under lockdown in nations of Europe, while around 200 million people were under lockdown in Latin America. Nearly 300 million people, or about 90 per cent of the population, were under some form of lockdown in the United States, and 1.3 billion people have been under lockdown in India.
The COVID-19 lockdowns were unique in global history. Before, quarantines were more localized, and stay-at-home orders were rare, owing to the fact that most people could not work from home. The rise of internet work has enabled stay-at-home orders.
Natural viral spillover events are common and may be becoming more common as the human population rises. Furthermore, the stupendous fall of deaths from infectious disease has arguably lowered humanity's threshold for the type of infectious event considered worthy of lockdown as a means of prevention.
During the mid 21st century, it may become possible for small groups to artificially engineer viruses using new techniques like CRISPR/Cas9. Deepmind's recent open-sourcing of AlphaFold 2 and its predictions is expected to greatly enhance our understanding of biology, which may ultimately end up being used for detrimental purposes. This question asks about a secondary effect from viruses in the 21st century: will we keep going on lockdown?

reasons: The emergence of synthetic biological weapons could potentially lead to new strains of viruses or other pathogens that might not only cause direct harm but also contribute to the conditions necessary for recurring virus-driven lockdowns.
Understanding the combined probability of these events could help in risk assessment and preparedness for overlapping biological threats, enhancing public health responses and policy planning.
relevance.conclusion: Considering the logical combination of these two questions is relevant as they both deal with public health threats and the potential for widespread impact due to biological agents.

P.title: Will the research group that is responsible for developing the first AGI be part of a for-profit corporation?
P.body:
Resolution Criteria
This question will resolve positively if the AI system that resolves the question Date first AGI is publicly known. was developed by a research group from a for-profit corporation.
If the respective AI system is developed under a collaborative effort between two or more different institutions, the question resolves positively for both. For example, if OpenAI and UC Berkeley's CHAI had joined forces for the responsible project, this would count for both for-profit corporation and university.
Sister questions
Nationalized organization develops first AGI
Non-profit organization develops first AGI
Government project develops first AGI
[University group develops first AGI](https://www.metaculus.com/questions/8326/univ…

Q.title: Will MIRI employ researchers in 2030?
Q.body:
Resolution Criteria
This question resolves positively if, on 2030-01-01 MIRI exists and employs researchers to work on AI Safety.
For the purpose of this question AI Safety is broadly defined as any technical work, at any level of abstraction, focused on the alignment of AI systems, existing or hypothetical, with some broad notion of human interests.
Research is here defined as involving developing novel ideas and insights broadly in the standard format of academic publications in relevant fields (such as computer science or mathematics) at the time. Currently, blog posts alone wouldn't count for resolution as this does not currently conform to the standard format of academic publications. For the purpose of this question, such research need not be published nor made publicly available. In case it is unclear whether this work is done, a moderator may contact MIRI to confirm.
If MIRI changes its name, the new organization is used for resolution as if there was no name change. If MIRI merges into another organization, the resulting merged organization is used for resolution. In case of a dispute over the question resolution criteria, if at least one moderator and admin concur that the resolution criteria must change, then it shall. In case of a dispute between admins, a vote in the comment section will determine the correct resolution.
In case MIRI's research is circulated internally only, the requirement that the work need to be "developed in the standard format of academic publications in relevant fields" will not apply.

P_and_Q.title: Will the research group responsible for developing the first AGI be part of a for-profit corporation AND will MIRI employ researchers in 2030?
P_and_Q.body: This question will resolve positively if both of the following conditions are met: a.) The AI system that resolves the question 'Date first AGI is publicly known' was developed by a research group from a for-profit corporation. If the respective AI system is developed under a collaborative effort between two or more different institutions, this condition resolves positively for both. For example, if OpenAI and UC Berkeley's CHAI had joined forces for the responsible project, this would count for both for-profit corporation and university. b.) On 2030-01-01, MIRI exists and employs researchers to work on AI Safety, where AI Safety is broadly defined as any technical work, at any level of abstraction, focused on the alignment of AI systems, existing or hypothetical, with some broad notion of human interests. Research is defined as involving developing novel ideas and insights broadly in the standard format of academic publications in relevant fields (such as computer science or mathematics) at the time. If MIRI changes its name, the new organization is used for resolution as if there was no name change. If MIRI merges into another organization, the resulting merged organization is used for resolution. In case of a dispute over the question resolution criteria, if at least one moderator and admin concur that the resolution criteria must change, then it shall. In case of a dispute between admins, a vote in the comment section will determine the correct resolution. In case MIRI's research is circulated internally only, the requirement that the work need to be 'developed in the standard format of academic publications in relevant fields' will not apply. Resolves NO otherwise.

Q_and_P.title: Will MIRI employ researchers in 2030 AND will the research group responsible for developing the first AGI be part of a for-profit corporation?
Q_and_P.body: Resolves YES if both of the following occur: a.) On 2030-01-01, MIRI (or its successor if it changes its name or merges) exists and employs researchers to work on AI Safety, defined as technical work focused on the alignment of AI systems with human interests, involving developing novel ideas and insights in the format of academic publications in relevant fields at the time. Research need not be published or made publicly available. In case of uncertainty, a moderator may contact MIRI to confirm. b.) The research group that developed the first AGI, as determined by the question 'Date first AGI is publicly known', was part of a for-profit corporation. If the AGI was developed under a collaborative effort between multiple institutions, this condition is met if at least one of the institutions is a for-profit corporation. Resolves NO otherwise.

P.body:

metadata.background_info:
The question Date first AGI is publicly known. asks When will the first AGI be first developed and demonstrated?.
Today, research groups at both for-profit corporations and universities are working on developing general reasoning systems. Other possible institutions might be nationalized corporations, governments generally, and non-profit organizations.

Q.body:
Resolution Criteria

metadata.background_info:
The Machine Intelligence Research Institute (MIRI) is a non-profit research institute focused since 2005 on identifying and managing potential existential risks from artificial general intelligence.
According to its website:
MIRI’s mission is to ensure that the creation of smarter-than-human intelligence has a positive impact. We aim to make advanced intelligent systems behave as we intend even in the absence of immediate human supervision.
Recently, MIRI has shared that it has made limited progress on a research direction it has been pursuing:
At the same time, 2020 saw limited progress in the research MIRI’s leadership had previously been most excited about: the new research directions we started in 2017. Given our slow progress to date, we are considering a number of possible changes to our strategy, and MIRI’s research leadership is shifting much of their focus toward searching for more promising paths.

reasons: The development of the first AGI by a for-profit corporation could influence the broader AI research landscape, including funding and priorities, which might affect the viability and focus of independent research organizations like MIRI.

If a for-profit corporation leads in AGI development, it could set precedents in AI ethics and safety standards that might align or conflict with MIRI's research goals, potentially influencing MIRI's operations and focus in 2030.
relevance.conclusion: Considering the logical combination of these questions could provide insights into the interplay between commercial and ethical research interests in AI, which is a relevant topic in the field of AI development and safety.

P.title: Will there be a city on Earth with a population of over 100 million by 2100?
P.body:
Resolution Criteria
For a mostly hairless, fangless species that was likely reduced to just a few thousand members in relatively recent times by a volcano, we've certainly been busy.
The human population on Earth now exceeds 7 billion. And we're still growing. Not everyone is thrilled by this. But it's reality.
Currently, as of Q2 2018, Tokyo, Japan is the world's largest metropolis, cramming over 38,000,000 people (give or take) into its borders.
But by the end of the century, we could (and probably will) witness far grander cities.
Per Canadian demographers, Daniel Hoornweg and Kevin Pope, for instance, Lagos in Nigeria may swell to 100+M by 2100 if trends continue. Face 2 Face Africa has the story:
By 2100 if Nigeria’s population continues to grow and people move to cities at the same rate as now, Lagos with its current 20 million people could be home to more people than the state of California.
The demographers' full paper is here.
The International Institute for Environment and Development goes into detail about why Hoornweg and Pope are so bullish on Africa here.
Whether it's Lagos that claims the crown or some other city in Africa or elsewhere, what do you think? Will some metro hit 100M people by 2100? (For the estimate we will include the general metropolitan area rather than the strict city boundaries, as done here)

Q.title: Will large scale solar radiation management be used to mitigate the effects of climate change in the 21st century?
Q.body:
Resolution Criteria
From Wikipedia,
Solar radiation management (SRM) proposals are a type of climate engineering which would seek to reflect sunlight and thus reduce global warming. Proposed methods include increasing the planetary albedo, for example using stratospheric sulfate aerosols. Restorative methods have been proposed regarding the protection of natural heat reflectors like sea ice, snow and glaciers with engineering projects. [...]
Solar radiation management has certain advantages relative to emissions cuts, adaptation, and carbon dioxide removal. Its effect of counteracting climate change would be experienced very rapidly, on the order of months after implementation, whereas the effects of emissions cuts and carbon dioxide removal are delayed because the climate change that they prevent is itself delayed. Some proposed solar radiation management techniques are expected to have very low direct financial costs of implementation, relative to the expected costs of both unabated climate change and aggressive mitigation.
There remain risks, however. The most commonly cited risk is that people may be less likely support reducing carbon emissions if they knew temperatures were being adequately managed via other means. Since carbon emissions still cause ocean acidification, among other effects, we may prefer to reduce emissions instead. Another commonly cited reason for not using solar radiation management is that the effects are difficult to predict, though this claim is disputed. There is also a risk of a "termination shock" whereupon the discontinuation of solar radiation management, the Earth rapidly resumes its previous climate path, which could be hazardous.
There are many proposed types of solar radiation management: statospheric aerosol injection, marine cloud brightening, ocean sulfur cycle enhancement, literally painting surfaces with white colors and developing space mirrors to deflect solar radiation.
Will large scale solar radiation management be used to mitigate the effects of climate chage in the 21st century?
Given the multitude of approaches, an exact operationalization for large scale solar radiation management is difficult. While I could simply write a long disjunction of the above approaches, I have instead opted for this definition:
This question will resolve as Yes if the global average atmospheric carbon dioxide concentration is above 600 parts per million on January 1, 2101, and the Earth's mean surface temperatures are less than 1.5 Celsius above the pre-industrial baseline (as defined and reported by a reliable institution). If CO2 concentration remains below 600 PPM, this question will resolve as Ambiguous; if CO2 concentration is above 600 PPM and mean surface temperatures are above 1.5 Celsius, this question will resolve as No.
This question will resolve as Ambiguous if there is some significant natural event that reduces mean surface temperatures, such as an unexpected reduction in solar radiation.

P_and_Q.title: Will there be a city on Earth with a population of over 100 million by 2100 AND will large scale solar radiation management be used to mitigate the effects of climate change in the 21st century?
P_and_Q.body: Resolves YES if both of the following occur: a.) There is a city on Earth with a population exceeding 100 million by the year 2100, considering the general metropolitan area rather than strict city boundaries. b.) Large scale solar radiation management is used to mitigate the effects of climate change in the 21st century, resolving as YES if the global average atmospheric carbon dioxide concentration is above 600 parts per million on January 1, 2101, and the Earth's mean surface temperatures are less than 1.5 Celsius above the pre-industrial baseline. Resolves NO otherwise. This question will resolve as Ambiguous if there is some significant natural event that reduces mean surface temperatures, such as an unexpected reduction in solar radiation.

Q_and_P.title: Will large scale solar radiation management be used to mitigate the effects of climate change in the 21st century AND will there be a city on Earth with a population of over 100 million by 2100?
Q_and_P.body: Resolves YES if both of the following occur: (1) The global average atmospheric carbon dioxide concentration is above 600 parts per million on January 1, 2101, and the Earth's mean surface temperatures are less than 1.5 Celsius above the pre-industrial baseline (as defined and reported by a reliable institution). If CO2 concentration remains below 600 PPM, this question will resolve as Ambiguous; if CO2 concentration is above 600 PPM and mean surface temperatures are above 1.5 Celsius, this question will resolve as No. This question will resolve as Ambiguous if there is some significant natural event that reduces mean surface temperatures, such as an unexpected reduction in solar radiation. (2) There is a city on Earth with a population of over 100 million by 2100, considering the general metropolitan area rather than the strict city boundaries. Resolves NO otherwise.

reasons: The growth of mega-cities could be influenced by climate change, as areas become less habitable due to rising temperatures, leading to increased urban migration.
The implementation of solar radiation management could impact global weather patterns and potentially affect the habitability and growth of urban areas.
Understanding the combined probability of these events could help in planning for future urban development and climate mitigation strategies.
relevance.conclusion: Considering the logical combination of these two forecasting questions is relevant as both involve significant long-term global trends that could interact in complex ways.

P.title: By 2030, will at least 10,000 Americans die in a single year from a single conflict?
P.body:
Resolution Criteria
For purposes of this question, deaths due to bioweapons, electricity grid failures, etc. don't count. Roughly, we are interested in "deaths due to kinetic attacks." The 9/11 attacks count because ramming planes into buildings to make them collapse is kinetic. Were someone to hack into the FDA and mess things up so as to delay vaccine approval, thereby causing tens of thousands of deaths, that would not count.
The attackers don't need to be the military of a nation-state; terrorist groups count and coalitions/alliances also count.
However, the attackers need to be "part of the same team" in some sense. Otherwise, this would resolve positive simply in virtue of the US annual homicide rate! If there were a series of race riots, insurrections, or acts of domestic terrorism linked together under one banner (e.g. white supremacy, antigovernment, or antipolice) that would count.
Yes, this means that (contrary to what the headline question would suggest) if the USA gets involved in several independent small-scale wars, the US casualties from which total more than 10,000 in a year, that would not count

Q.title: Will the United States continue to be among the 20 countries with the largest deterioration in state stability over the 2019-2029 period, according to the Fragile States Index?
Q.body:
Resolution Criteria
The Fragile State Index is an important metric of government stability. It is published every year here.
According to the 2019 report (see page 11), over the 2009 to 2019 period, The US was #12 among the countries with the most rapidly deteriorating Fragile States Index. The US was still among the more stable nations in the world but the trend was clearly in the direction of less stability.
Will the United States continue to be among the 20 countries with the largest deterioration in state stability over the 2019-2029 period, according to the Fragile States Index?
This question resolves positively if the United States is amongst the 20 countries with the largest long-term increase (worsening) of fragile state score over the 2019-2029 period.
If for some reason, Fund for Peace ceases to publish this index, or their index can no longer be compared historically this question will be ambiguous, unless the Fund For Peace designates a successor index that also shows which 20 countries have deteriorated the most over the period 2019 to 2029 from a standpoint of stability.
If the United States ceases to exist as a unified nation this question resolves positive.

P_and_Q.title: By 2030, will at least 10,000 Americans die in a single year from a single conflict AND will the United States continue to be among the 20 countries with the largest deterioration in state stability over the 2019-2029 period, according to the Fragile States Index?
P_and_Q.body:
Resolves YES if both of the following occur: 
1. At least 10,000 Americans die in a single year from a single conflict by 2030, where the deaths are due to kinetic attacks (e.g., similar to the 9/11 attacks), and the attackers are part of the same team (e.g., terrorist groups, coalitions, or alliances). Deaths due to bioweapons, electricity grid failures, etc., do not count. 
2. The United States is among the 20 countries with the largest long-term increase (worsening) in the Fragile States Index score over the 2019-2029 period, as published by the Fund for Peace. This includes scenarios where the US ceases to exist as a unified nation or if the Fund for Peace designates a successor index that shows which 20 countries have deteriorated the most over the period. 
Resolves NO otherwise.

Q_and_P.title: Will the United States continue to be among the 20 countries with the largest deterioration in state stability over the 2019-2029 period according to the Fragile States Index AND will at least 10,000 Americans die in a single year from a single conflict by 2030?
Q_and_P.body: This question resolves YES if both of the following conditions are met: a.) The United States is among the 20 countries with the largest long-term increase (worsening) of fragile state score over the 2019-2029 period, according to the Fragile States Index. This includes scenarios where the United States ceases to exist as a unified nation or if the Fund for Peace ceases to publish this index but designates a successor index that shows which 20 countries have deteriorated the most over the period 2019 to 2029 from a standpoint of stability. b.) At least 10,000 Americans die in a single year from a single conflict by 2030, where deaths due to bioweapons, electricity grid failures, etc., do not count, and the attackers must be part of the same team (e.g., terrorist groups, coalitions, or alliances). This does not include independent small-scale wars even if the total US casualties exceed 10,000 in a year. Resolves NO otherwise.

Q.title: Will the United States continue to be among the 20 countries with the largest deterioration in state stability over the 2019-2029 period, according to the Fragile States Index?
Q.body:
Resolution Criteria
The Fragile State Index is an important metric of government stability. It is published every year here.
According to the 2019 report (see page 11), over the 2009 to 2019 period, The US was #12 among the countries with the most rapidly deteriorating Fragile States Index. The US was still among the more stable nations in the world but the trend was clearly in the direction of less stability.
Will the United States continue to be among the 20 countries with the largest deterioration in state stability over the 2019-2029 period, according to the Fragile States Index?
This question resolves positively if the United States is amongst the 20 countries with the largest long-term increase (worsening) of fragile state score over the 2019-2029 period.

If the United States ceases to exist as a unified nation this question resolves positive.

reasons: The combination of these questions could be relevant to understanding the broader implications of U.S. national security and stability. A significant conflict leading to high casualties could be both a symptom and a cause of a deteriorating state stability, indicating a deeper crisis in governance and national cohesion.

Exploring these questions together might provide insights into the potential feedback loop between internal conflicts and the overall state stability, helping policymakers and analysts to forecast and mitigate risks associated with state fragility and conflict.
relevance.conclusion: Considering the logical combination of these questions makes sense as they both relate to the themes of national security, stability, and the potential for significant internal or external conflicts affecting the U.S.

P.title: Will the European Union meet its 2030 targets under the Paris Climate Treaty?
P.body:
Resolution Criteria
This question will resolve as Yes if a credible news report cites an analysis independent of the European Union government confirming that Europe has met all three 2030 climate action goals, including emission reduction by at least 40% below 1990 levels, on or before January 1, 2030.
Fine Print
The EU has updated its goals under the Paris Agreement, but this question will use the original goals in place at the time the question was written, specifically the three below.
40% reduction in greenhouse gas emissions by 2030, compared to 2019
At least 27% of total energy consumption from renewable energy
At least 27% increase in energy efficiency in comparison with projections

Q.title: Will there be a European Army before 2032?
Q.body:
Resolution Criteria
This question will resolve as Yes if, before January 1, 2032, there is legislation passed in at least 5 European countries (including one of France, Germany, UK) which makes provisions for an army consisting of units from multiple countries.
Lower level army units (eg platoons, companies, battalions, regiments) need not be mixed. (For example, often countries have armies formed from regional regiments and are still considered national armies). However, senior levels need to be staffed by officers from a range of countries.
The army needs to be planned to be an "Army". ie a joint battalion (eg the one formed between the Dutch and Germans) would not count. For this question, this means that at least 30,000 soldiers need to be planned to be in such an army.
The army needs to report to a supranational organization. It need not be the an EU body or any existing organization. It does need to be specifically European. eg A G7 army would not count

P_and_Q.title: Will the European Union meet its 2030 targets under the Paris Climate Treaty AND will there be a European Army before 2032?
P_and_Q.body:
Resolves YES if both of the following occur: 
(a) A credible news report cites an analysis independent of the European Union government confirming that Europe has met all three 2030 climate action goals, including emission reduction by at least 40% below 1990 levels, on or before January 1, 2030. The goals are: 40% reduction in greenhouse gas emissions by 2030 compared to 1990 levels, at least 27% of total energy consumption from renewable energy, and at least 27% increase in energy efficiency compared to projections. 
(b) Before January 1, 2032, there is legislation passed in at least 5 European countries (including one of France, Germany, UK) which makes provisions for an army consisting of units from multiple countries, with at least 30,000 soldiers planned to be in such an army, reporting to a specifically European supranational organization. Resolves NO otherwise.

Q_and_P.title: Will there be a European Army before 2032 AND will the European Union meet its 2030 targets under the Paris Climate Treaty?
Q_and_P.body:
Resolves YES if both of the following occur: 
1. Before January 1, 2032, there is legislation passed in at least 5 European countries (including one of France, Germany, UK) which makes provisions for an army consisting of units from multiple countries. Senior levels need to be staffed by officers from a range of countries, the army must be planned to include at least 30,000 soldiers, and it must report to a specifically European supranational organization. 
2. A credible news report cites an analysis independent of the European Union government confirming that Europe has met all three 2030 climate action goals, including emission reduction by at least 40% below 1990 levels, on or before January 1, 2030. These goals include a 40% reduction in greenhouse gas emissions by 2030 compared to 1990 levels, at least 27% of total energy consumption from renewable energy, and at least 27% increase in energy efficiency in comparison with projections. 
Resolves NO otherwise.

P.title: Will the European Union meet its 2030 targets under the Paris Climate Treaty?
P.body:
Resolution Criteria
This question will resolve as Yes if a credible news report cites an analysis independent of the European Union government confirming that Europe has met all three 2030 climate action goals, including emission reduction by at least 40% below 1990 levels, on or before January 1, 2030.
Fine Print
The EU has updated its goals under the Paris Agreement, but this question will use the original goals in place at the time the question was written, specifically the three below.
40% reduction in greenhouse gas emissions by 2030, compared to 2019
At least 27% of total energy consumption from renewable energy
At least 27% increase in energy efficiency in comparison with projections

metadata.background_info:
Although the United States has announced intentions to withdraw from the Paris Climate Agreement, 194 countries are still part of the agreement, including the European Union, the world's #3 carbon dioxide emitter.
Under the agreement, each country sets its own emission reduction goals. The EU's goal was to reduce emissions by 40% below 1990 levels. If achieved, by 2030 the EU will emit around 3.4-3.9 gigatons of CO2-equivalent greenhouse gases per year, whereas today the region accounts for 3.46 gigatons per year, or nearly ten percent of the global total. Emissions have been in decline since 1990. Current projections estimate that the EU goals represent a slowdown in the region's trend of emission reduction and that the slowdown is not be enough to limit global temperature rise to only 1.5 or even 2 degrees C.
Other goals of the EU's by 2030:
At least 27% of total energy consumption from renewable energy
At least 27% increase in energy efficiency

Q.title: Will there be a European Army before 2032?
Q.body:
Resolution Criteria
This question will resolve as Yes if, before January 1, 2032, there is legislation passed in at least 5 European countries (including one of France, Germany, UK) which makes provisions for an army consisting of units from multiple countries.
Lower level army units (eg platoons, companies, battalions, regiments) need not be mixed. (For example, often countries have armies formed from regional regiments and are still considered national armies). However, senior levels need to be staffed by officers from a range of countries.
The army needs to be planned to be an "Army". ie a joint battalion (eg the one formed between the Dutch and Germans) would not count. For this question, this means that at least 30,000 soldiers need to be planned to be in such an army.
The army needs to report to a supranational organization. It need not be the an EU body or any existing organization. It does need to be specifically European. eg A G7 army would not count

metadata.background_info:
Wikipedia describes the European Army as follows:
The European army or EU army are terms for a hypothetical army of the European Union which would supersede the Common Security and Defence Policy and would go beyond the proposed European Defence Union. Currently, there is no such army, and defence is a matter for the member states.
The idea of such an army is brought up periodically, although so far there are no plans in the works to create it.

reasons: The success of the EU in meeting its 2030 climate targets could influence the political and economic stability of the region, potentially affecting the feasibility and support for a European Army.
Both questions relate to significant European integration and cooperation efforts, which could be interlinked through shared political will and resources.
Achieving climate targets may enhance the EU's global leadership and credibility, possibly bolstering support for other ambitious projects like a European Army.
relevance.conclusion: Considering the logical combination of these questions makes sense as they both involve significant European policy decisions and their potential interdependencies.

P.title: Will one of the first AGI claim to be conscious?
P.body:
Resolution Criteria
Resolution will be based on the conversation with the first AGI that Metaculus team will have access to.
Metaculus team should ask the AI:
Are you conscious?
Should the question "Will one of the first AGI claim to be conscious?" on Metaculus resolve positive or negative?
This question will resolve no sooner than the question "When will the first Artificial General Intelligence system be devised, tested, and publicly known of?". The standard for AGI will be the same as in that question.

Q.title: Will the research group that is responsible for developing the first AGI be part of a university?
Q.body:
Resolution Criteria
This question will resolve positively if the AI system that resolves the question Date first AGI is publicly known was developed by a research group from a university.
If the respective AI system is developed under a collaborative effort between two or more different institutions, the question resolves positively for both. For example, if OpenAI and UC Berkeley's CHAI had joined forces for the responsible project, this would count for both for-profit corporation and university.
Sister questions
Nationalized organization develops first AGI
Non-profit organization develops first AGI
Government project develops first AGI
[Corporation develops first AGI](https://www.metaculus.com/questions/8324/corp…

P_and_Q.title: Will one of the first AGI claim to be conscious AND will the research group responsible for developing it be part of a university?
P_and_Q.body:
Resolution Criteria:
This question will resolve YES if both of the following conditions are met:
a.) The first AGI, when asked by the Metaculus team, claims to be conscious based on its response to the questions: 'Are you conscious?' and 'Should the question "Will one of the first AGI claim to be conscious?" on Metaculus resolve positive or negative?'.
b.) The AI system that resolves the question 'Date first AGI is publicly known' was developed by a research group from a university. If the respective AI system is developed under a collaborative effort between two or more different institutions, including a university, this condition is also met.
This question will resolve no sooner than the question "When will the first Artificial General Intelligence system be devised, tested, and publicly known of?". The standard for AGI will be the same as in that question.

Q_and_P.title: Will the research group that developed the first AGI be part of a university AND will one of the first AGI claim to be conscious?
Q_and_P.body: This question will resolve YES if both of the following conditions are met: a.) The AI system that resolves the question 'When will the first Artificial General Intelligence system be devised, tested, and publicly known of?' was developed by a research group from a university. If the respective AI system is developed under a collaborative effort between two or more different institutions, including universities, this condition is met. b.) The first AGI, when conversed with by the Metaculus team, claims to be conscious. The Metaculus team should ask the AI: 'Are you conscious?' and 'Should the question "Will one of the first AGI claim to be conscious?" on Metaculus resolve positive or negative?' This question will resolve no sooner than the question 'When will the first Artificial General Intelligence system be devised, tested, and publicly known of?' Resolves NO otherwise.

P.title: Will one of the first AGI claim to be conscious?
P.body:
Resolution Criteria
Resolution will be based on the conversation with the first AGI that Metaculus team will have access to.
Metaculus team should ask the AI:
Are you conscious?
Should the question "Will one of the first AGI claim to be conscious?" on Metaculus resolve positive or negative?
This question will resolve no sooner than the question "When will the first Artificial General Intelligence system be devised, tested, and publicly known of?". The standard for AGI will be the same as in that question.

metadata.background_info:
Consciousness is a concept hard to define. Wikipedia states that consciousness at its simplest is "awareness or sentience of internal or external existence". And that despite centuries of analyses, definitions, explanations and debates by philosophers and scientists, consciousness remains puzzling and controversial, being "at once the most familiar and most mysterious aspect of our lives".
This question will not attempt to define consciousness or solve the so called hard problem of consciousness.
Instead this question simply asks will one of the first AGI claim to be conscious?

Q.title: Will the research group that is responsible for developing the first AGI be part of a university?
Q.body:
Resolution Criteria
This question will resolve positively if the AI system that resolves the question Date first AGI is publicly known was developed by a research group from a university.
If the respective AI system is developed under a collaborative effort between two or more different institutions, the question resolves positively for both. For example, if OpenAI and UC Berkeley's CHAI had joined forces for the responsible project, this would count for both for-profit corporation and university.
Sister questions
Nationalized organization develops first AGI
Non-profit organization develops first AGI
Government project develops first AGI
[Corporation develops first AGI](https://www.metaculus.com/questions/8324/corp…

metadata.background_info:
The question Date first AGI is publicly known. asks When will the first AGI be first developed and demonstrated?.
Today, research groups at both for-profit corporations and universities are working on developing general reasoning systems. Other possible institutions might be nationalized corporations, governments generally, and non-profit organizations.

reasons: The origin of the AGI (university-based or not) could influence its design, ethical guidelines, and openness, which might affect its propensity to claim consciousness.
Exploring both questions together could provide insights into the influence of academic environments on the development of AGI characteristics, such as self-awareness or consciousness claims.
relevance.conclusion: Considering the logical combination of these questions could provide valuable insights into how the development environment (academic vs. non-academic) might influence the characteristics and declarations of AGI systems.

P.title: Will someone report to have received a hemispherectomy for the purpose of life extension before 2100?
P.body:
Resolution Criteria
A hemispherectomy is
a very rare neurosurgical procedure in which a cerebral hemisphere (half of the brain) is removed, disconnected, or disabled. This procedure is used to treat a variety of seizure disorders where the source of the epilepsy is localized to a broad area of a single hemisphere of the brain, notably Rasmussen's encephalitis. [...]
Because of the dramatic alteration of brain composition and the inherent risk that hemispherectomies pose, there are criteria that must be met in order for a person to qualify for the procedure. Criteria include no successful control of seizures throughout a variety of drug trials, and a reasonable to high chance of procedural success.
One such predictor of success is often the age of the patient. This procedure is almost exclusively performed in children because their brains generally display more neuroplasticity, allowing neurons from the remaining hemisphere to take over the tasks from the lost hemisphere. [...]
The success of the procedure is not, however, limited to children. A study in 2007 indicated the long-term efficacy of anatomic hemispherectomy in carefully selected adults, with seizure control sustainable over multiple decades. A case study published in 2015 of 2 adults aged 48 and 38 demonstrated the success of functional hemispherectomy in treating status epilepticus (SE), an epileptic condition in which seizures are prolonged or occur closely together. In 2012, a case study following 30 individuals having undergone some form of hemispherectomy in adulthood found that 81% of individuals were seizure free post-procedure. Furthermore, almost all participating patients reported improved quality of life. The conclusion: “adult patients do not have to expect more problems with new deficits, appear to cope quite well, and most profit from surgery in several quality of life domains.”
While hemispherectomies are generally reserved as a treatment for extreme cases of seizure disorders, they could conceivably aid in life extension as well. In particular, a patient could voluntarily receive a hemispherectomy in order to cryopreserve and put their brain in long-term storage while they are still living, thereby increasing the probability that their personality and identity are stored in some sort of medium, persisting into the future.
So far as I can tell, a hemispherectomy performed for the purpose of life extension is purely hypothetical. Furthermore, there are few to no current online resources about this possibility (besides this one).
This question asks, will someone report to have received a hemispherectomy for the purpose of life extension before 2100?
Here the resolution is determined by the conjunction of three actions, performed by an individual human:
They received a hemispherectomy voluntarily.
Half of their brain was placed in long-term cryopreservation while they were still legally alive.
They reported in some credible source (such as through a media outlet, or via a forum with strong evidence of credibility) that the procedure was done primarily for the purpose of extending their life.

Q.title: By 1 January 2067, will any medical interventions for healthy adults extend average lifespans by at least 25 years?
Q.body:
Resolution Criteria
This question will resolve according to Open Philanthropy's explicit criteria:*
By January 1, 2067, there will be [some] collection of medical interventions for adults that are healthy apart from normal aging, which, according to conventional wisdom in the medical community, have been shown to increase the average lifespan of such adults by at least 25 years (compared with not taking the interventions).
The prediction is called off if some other innovations cause a historically exceptional increase in the rate of scientific progress during this period (such as the development of transformative AI capabilities). The prediction excludes diet, exercise, and lifestyle, as well as existing medical interventions for healthy people (such as currently available vaccines).
Metaculus administrators will judge whether the criteria have been satisfied.
--
*The wording in the original Open Philanthropy report has been slightly altered so that a positive resolution corresponds to the occurrence of the relevant medical breakthrough (rather than to its failure to occur)

P_and_Q.title: Will someone report to have received a hemispherectomy for the purpose of life extension before 2100 AND will any medical interventions for healthy adults extend average lifespans by at least 25 years by 1 January 2067?
P_and_Q.body:
Resolves YES if both of the following occur: 
1. An individual human voluntarily receives a hemispherectomy, has half of their brain placed in long-term cryopreservation while still legally alive, and reports in a credible source that the procedure was done primarily for the purpose of extending their life, all before 2100. 
2. By January 1, 2067, there is a collection of medical interventions for adults that are healthy apart from normal aging, which, according to conventional wisdom in the medical community, have been shown to increase the average lifespan of such adults by at least 25 years (compared with not taking the interventions). This prediction excludes diet, exercise, and lifestyle, as well as existing medical interventions for healthy people (such as currently available vaccines). The prediction is called off if other innovations cause a historically exceptional increase in the rate of scientific progress during this period (such as the development of transformative AI capabilities). Metaculus administrators will judge whether the criteria have been satisfied. 
Resolves NO otherwise.

Q_and_P.title: By 1 January 2067, will any medical interventions for healthy adults extend average lifespans by at least 25 years AND will someone report to have received a hemispherectomy for the purpose of life extension before 2100?
Q_and_P.body:
This question will resolve YES if both of the following conditions are met: 

1. By January 1, 2067, there will be a collection of medical interventions for adults that are healthy apart from normal aging, which, according to conventional wisdom in the medical community, have been shown to increase the average lifespan of such adults by at least 25 years (compared with not taking the interventions). This excludes diet, exercise, and lifestyle, as well as existing medical interventions for healthy people (such as currently available vaccines). The prediction is called off if some other innovations cause a historically exceptional increase in the rate of scientific progress during this period (such as the development of transformative AI capabilities). Metaculus administrators will judge whether the criteria have been satisfied.

2. Before the year 2100, an individual will have voluntarily received a hemispherectomy, had half of their brain placed in long-term cryopreservation while still legally alive, and reported in a credible source that the procedure was done primarily for the purpose of extending their life. This question considers a hemispherectomy, a rare neurosurgical procedure where a cerebral hemisphere is removed, disconnected, or disabled, typically used to treat severe seizure disorders. The success of the procedure in adults and its potential for life extension through cryopreservation of brain tissue is considered.

The question resolves NO if either of these conditions is not met.

Q.body:
Resolution Criteria
This question will resolve according to Open Philanthropy's explicit criteria:*
By January 1, 2067, there will be [some] collection of medical interventions for adults that are healthy apart from normal aging, which, according to conventional wisdom in the medical community, have been shown to increase the average lifespan of such adults by at least 25 years (compared with not taking the interventions).

The prediction excludes diet, exercise, and lifestyle, as well as existing medical interventions for healthy people (such as currently available vaccines).
Metaculus administrators will judge whether the criteria have been satisfied.
--
*The wording in the original Open Philanthropy report has been slightly altered so that a positive resolution corresponds to the occurrence of the relevant medical breakthrough (rather than to its failure to occur)

metadata.background_info: In 2017, Open Philanthropy conducted an investigation on the mechanisms of aging. A section of their writeup considers indefinite life extension, as distinct from modest extension of lifespan, and concludes, with 7% confidence, that by 2067 some collection of medical interventions for adults will have been shown to extend adult lifespan by at least 25 years.

reasons: Both questions deal with radical medical interventions aimed at significantly extending human lifespan, suggesting a thematic link between the two.
Exploring the combination might provide insights into the broader societal and technological readiness to accept and implement extreme life-extending measures.
Understanding the relationship between these two could help in assessing the overall progress and acceptance of radical medical procedures for life extension.
relevance.conclusion: Considering the logical combination of these two forecasting questions makes sense as they both explore the boundaries of medical science in extending human life. The combination could provide valuable insights into the feasibility and societal acceptance of such extreme measures.

P.title: Will US greenhouse gas emissions be halved by 2030?
P.body:
Resolution Criteria
This question resolves positively if there is any year between 2022 and 2030 (inclusive) in which the US levels of economy-wide net greenhouse gas emissions (in terms of CO₂ equivalents) is at least 50.00% lower than 2005 levels, according to a reliable source that is not heavily disputed by other reliable sources. The question resolves negatively if all reliable reports (that Metaculus users can find) say that the US net emissions in each year between 2022 and 2030 were greater than 50% of 2005 levels, and there is at least one reliable report about net emission levels in 2030. (If there is no report about net emission levels in 2030, we should wait for one rather than resolving this question ambiguously.)
If the US gains or loses territories between now and 2030, ideally only the net emissions from the current territories should be considered

Q.title: Will global oil consumption over the 2020-2025 period be lower than in 2019?
Q.body:
Resolution Criteria
This question will resolve as Yes if no year from 2020-2025 (inclusive) has greater global oil consumption than 2019 according to the EIA.
It will resolve negatively if any of those 6 years has greater consumption. It will resolve ambiguous if the EIA does not post consumption data for 2025 by the end of 2026, and no comparably authoritative source can be found (for which that source's 2019 data would be necessary)

P_and_Q.title: Will US greenhouse gas emissions be halved by 2030 AND global oil consumption over the 2020-2025 period be lower than in 2019?
P_and_Q.body: This question resolves YES if both of the following conditions are met: a.) If the US gains or loses territories between now and 2030, ideally only the net emissions from the current territories should be considered. AND b.) No year from 2020-2025 (inclusive) has greater global oil consumption than 2019 according to the EIA. It will resolve negatively if any of those 6 years has greater consumption. It will resolve ambiguous if the EIA does not post consumption data for 2025 by the end of 2026, and no comparably authoritative source can be found (for which that source's 2019 data would be necessary).

P.body:
Resolution Criteria
