metadata.background_info:
Risks from Artificial intelligence are considered by many to be one of the greatest threats to human civilisation in the coming centuries.
In Toby Ord's recent book The Precipice he places the risk of human extinction due to unaligned AI this century at 10%.
This question asks if we will see large scale incidents leading to loss of life or damage as a result of AI developments going wrong in the next ten years.

Q.title: Will the first AGI be based on deep learning?
Q.body:
Resolution Criteria
Assume for the purpose of this question, that this question resolves on some date.
Metaculus admin(s) and/or community moderator(s) will survey 11 AI researchers whose work they consider relevant and whose work has been cited at least 500 times within the past 365 days according to Google Scholar. We will then ask about the relevant AI system:
Was the relevant AI system based on Deep Learning, as defined by the 2016 version of the Deep Learning Book?
Respondents will be requested to submit only one of the following responses:
The complete system was based on DL
Most of system was based on DL
At least a significant portion of the system was based on DL
Only a minor portion of the system was based on DL
No portion, or only a trivial portion of the system was based on DL
I don't know
Then the question resolves positively if a majority of surveyed experts who don't respond "I don't know" respond as follows:
The complete system was based on DL
Most of system was based on DL
The question resolves ambiguously if a majority of experts respond "I don't know".

metadata.background_info:
The Deep Learning Book, which is considered by many to be the best reference textbook on the topic, introduces deep learning,
This book is about a solution to [fuzzy ill-defined problems]. This solution is to allow computers to learn from experience and understand the world in terms of a hierarchy of concepts, with each concept deﬁned through its relation to simpler concepts. By gathering knowledge from experience, this approach avoids the need for human operators to formally specify all the knowledge that the computer needs. The hierarchy of concepts enables the computer to learn complicated concepts by building them out of simpler ones. If we draw a graph showing how these concepts are built on top of each other, the graph is deep, with many layers. For this reason,we call this approach to AI deep learning
Paul Christiano has written that future AGI might be based on deep learning principles,
It now seems possible that we could build “prosaic” AGI, which can replicate human behavior but doesn’t involve qualitatively new ideas about “how intelligence works:”
It’s plausible that a large neural network can replicate “fast” human cognition, and that by coupling it to simple computational mechanisms — short and long-term memory, attention, etc. — we could obtain a human-level computational architecture.
It’s plausible that a variant of RL can train this architecture to actually implement human-level cognition. This would likely involve some combination of ingredients like model-based RL, imitation learning, or hierarchical RL. There are a whole bunch of ideas currently on the table and being explored; if you can’t imagine any of these ideas working out, then I feel that’s a failure of imagination (unless you see something I don’t).

reasons: The connection between an AI malfunction causing significant harm and the technological basis of the first AGI (whether it is based on deep learning or not) could be relevant for understanding the potential risks and safety measures needed in future AI developments. If the first AGI is based on deep learning and there are catastrophic malfunctions in other AI systems also based on deep learning, this might indicate a need for caution or additional safety protocols in AGI development.

Exploring this combination could help in risk assessment and management for future AI technologies, especially in understanding how foundational technologies influence the behavior and reliability of advanced AI systems.
relevance.conclusion: Considering the logical combination of these questions is relevant as it helps in understanding the implications of AI technology foundations on safety and risk management.

P.title: Will there be a 4 year interval in which world output doubles before 2050?
P.body:
Resolution Criteria
Resolution is by credible assessment of world GDP in constant US dollars (or other appropriately widely-accepted units).
This question will resolve positively if world output doubles in a period of 4 years or less before 2050. It resolves negatively otherwise, i.e. if the following related question resolves ambiguously:
[Will there be a complete 4 year interval in which world output doubles, before the first 1 year interval in which world output doubles?](https://www.metaculus.com/questions/736/will-…

Q.title: By 2030, will at least 1% of Gallup respondents report the most important problem facing the US is something relating to space?
Q.body:
Resolution Criteria
This question resolves positively if before Jan 1, 2030, Gallup announces a poll, as part of its “Most Important Problem” series, showing that 1% of Americans responded with an answer referring to space or space governance.
Fine Print
Answers to the Gallup poll which refer to space or space governance include:
Any answer which refers to an aerospace organization, program or object, such as “NASA” or “Sputnik”.
Any answer which directly refers to something related to space governance. This does not include indirect references, such as “foreign policy” (even if space governance is at the time an important part of foreign policy). This is to be decided by Metaculus moderators.
If the Gallup poll is discontinued the question resolves ambiguously.

P_and_Q.title: Will there be a 4 year interval in which world output doubles before 2050 AND by 2030, will at least 1% of Gallup respondents report the most important problem facing the US is something relating to space?
P_and_Q.body:
Resolution Criteria for both parts:
1. The first part resolves positively if world output doubles in a period of 4 years or less before 2050, based on a credible assessment of world GDP in constant US dollars or other appropriately widely-accepted units. It resolves negatively otherwise, including if the related question about the sequence of doubling intervals resolves ambiguously.
2. The second part resolves positively if before Jan 1, 2030, Gallup announces a poll, as part of its “Most Important Problem” series, showing that 1% of Americans responded with an answer referring to space or space governance. Answers qualifying for this include references to aerospace organizations, programs, or objects (e.g., 'NASA', 'Sputnik'), or direct references to space governance. Indirect references such as 'foreign policy' do not qualify, even if space governance is an important part of foreign policy at the time. This is to be decided by Metaculus moderators. If the Gallup poll is discontinued, the question resolves ambiguously.

This question will resolve positively if both parts resolve positively, and negatively otherwise.

Q_and_P.title: By 2030, will at least 1% of Gallup respondents report the most important problem facing the US is something relating to space AND will there be a 4 year interval in which world output doubles before 2050?
Q_and_P.body:
Resolution Criteria for both parts:

1. The first part resolves positively if before Jan 1, 2030, Gallup announces a poll, as part of its “Most Important Problem” series, showing that 1% of Americans responded with an answer referring to space or space governance. Answers to the Gallup poll which refer to space or space governance include any answer which refers to an aerospace organization, program or object, such as “NASA” or “Sputnik”, and any answer which directly refers to something related to space governance. This does not include indirect references, such as “foreign policy” (even if space governance is at the time an important part of foreign policy). This is to be decided by Metaculus moderators. If the Gallup poll is discontinued the question resolves ambiguously.

2. The second part resolves positively if world output doubles in a period of 4 years or less before 2050, based on a credible assessment of world GDP in constant US dollars (or other appropriately widely-accepted units). It resolves negatively otherwise.

This question resolves YES if both parts resolve positively. It resolves NO otherwise.

P.title: Will there be a 4 year interval in which world output doubles before 2050?
P.body:
Resolution Criteria
Resolution is by credible assessment of world GDP in constant US dollars (or other appropriately widely-accepted units).
This question will resolve positively if world output doubles in a period of 4 years or less before 2050. It resolves negatively otherwise, i.e. if the following related question resolves ambiguously:
[Will there be a complete 4 year interval in which world output doubles, before the first 1 year interval in which world output doubles?](https://www.metaculus.com/questions/736/will-…

metadata.background_info:
Related Questions on Metaculus:
Will there be a complete 4 year interval in which world output doubles, before the first 1 year interval in which world output doubles?
Will there be a complete 4 year interval in which world output doubles, before the first 1 year interval in which world output doubles?
As of 2018, it's taken about 16 years for the world economic output to double. So it might seem absurd to talk about it doubling in one or even four years. But there is a potential major change on the horizon: very advanced Artificial Intelligence.
An important consideration in how to approach the AI alignment problem is the speed of the takeoff from massively subhuman AI to massively superhuman AI. The effectiveness of capacity limitation, as well as the existence of fire alarms for AI safety, are heavily dependent on this, for example.
Paul Christiano suggests operationalising the takeoff speed in terms of economic growth. A slow takeoff is one where the economy doubles in four years before the first time it doubles in one year, and a fast takeoff is one where it does not. (See the same article for Christiano's list of arguments regarding fast vs. slow takeoff.)

Q.title: By 2030, will at least 1% of Gallup respondents report the most important problem facing the US is something relating to space?
Q.body:
Resolution Criteria
This question resolves positively if before Jan 1, 2030, Gallup announces a poll, as part of its “Most Important Problem” series, showing that 1% of Americans responded with an answer referring to space or space governance.
Fine Print
Answers to the Gallup poll which refer to space or space governance include:
Any answer which refers to an aerospace organization, program or object, such as “NASA” or “Sputnik”.
Any answer which directly refers to something related to space governance. This does not include indirect references, such as “foreign policy” (even if space governance is at the time an important part of foreign policy). This is to be decided by Metaculus moderators.
If the Gallup poll is discontinued the question resolves ambiguously.

metadata.background_info:
The policy and politics surrounding space governance may have enormous consequences for humanity’s long-term future. Yet, there is currently relatively little interest in the area. 80,000 Hours lists space governance as among the potential highest priorities for improving the long-term future, saying that:
Despite the huge stakes, governance of space is an extremely niche area of study and advocacy. As a result, major progress could probably be made by a research community focused on this issue, even just by applying familiar lessons from related fields of law and social science.
Whether this is true may depend on how politically charged the topic becomes. How interested the public is in the topic may reflect or create political interest, and therefore bears on how influential a small research community could be. The interest of the American public is especially important, as America is home to some of the world’s largest space related organizations, such as NASA, SpaceX, Blue Origin and Virgin Galactic.
Since 1933, the Gallup polling organization has asked Americans the question: “What do you think is the most important problem facing this country today?".

reasons: The doubling of world output could lead to increased investments and focus on space exploration and technology, potentially making space-related issues more prominent in public discourse.
A significant economic boom might shift public priorities and concerns, possibly increasing the attention towards space exploration as a frontier for further economic opportunities.
relevance.conclusion: While the connection between these two events is not direct, there is a plausible link through economic growth influencing public interest and policy priorities, which could make the combination of these questions relevant for understanding broader socio-economic trends.

P.title: Will Kessler syndrome occur before 2050?
P.body:
Resolution Criteria
This question will resolve as Yes if between 2018 to 2049 (inclusive), there is at least one calendar year when 10% or more of Earth's operational satellites become inoperable due to collisions with space debris

Q.title: Will there be a city on Earth with a population of over 100 million by 2100?
Q.body:
Resolution Criteria
For a mostly hairless, fangless species that was likely reduced to just a few thousand members in relatively recent times by a volcano, we've certainly been busy.
The human population on Earth now exceeds 7 billion. And we're still growing. Not everyone is thrilled by this. But it's reality.
Currently, as of Q2 2018, Tokyo, Japan is the world's largest metropolis, cramming over 38,000,000 people (give or take) into its borders.
But by the end of the century, we could (and probably will) witness far grander cities.
Per Canadian demographers, Daniel Hoornweg and Kevin Pope, for instance, Lagos in Nigeria may swell to 100+M by 2100 if trends continue. Face 2 Face Africa has the story:
By 2100 if Nigeria’s population continues to grow and people move to cities at the same rate as now, Lagos with its current 20 million people could be home to more people than the state of California.
The demographers' full paper is here.
The International Institute for Environment and Development goes into detail about why Hoornweg and Pope are so bullish on Africa here.
Whether it's Lagos that claims the crown or some other city in Africa or elsewhere, what do you think? Will some metro hit 100M people by 2100? (For the estimate we will include the general metropolitan area rather than the strict city boundaries, as done here)

P_and_Q.title: Will Kessler syndrome occur before 2050 AND will there be a city on Earth with a population of over 100 million by 2100?
P_and_Q.body:
Resolution Criteria for Kessler syndrome: This question will resolve as YES if between 2018 to 2049 (inclusive), there is at least one calendar year when 10% or more of Earth's operational satellites become inoperable due to collisions with space debris.

Resolution Criteria for city population: This question will resolve as YES if by the end of the century (2100), there is at least one city on Earth with a population exceeding 100 million people, considering the general metropolitan area rather than strict city boundaries.

The question resolves YES if both conditions are met. It resolves NO otherwise.

Q_and_P.title: Will there be a city on Earth with a population of over 100 million by 2100 AND will Kessler syndrome occur before 2050?
Q_and_P.body:
Resolution Criteria for both events:
1. For the first part, this question will resolve as YES if by the end of the century (2100), there is at least one city on Earth with a population exceeding 100 million people. This includes considering the general metropolitan area rather than strict city boundaries. Current trends suggest cities like Lagos could reach such numbers.
2. For the second part, this question will resolve as YES if between 2018 to 2049 (inclusive), there is at least one calendar year when 10% or more of Earth's operational satellites become inoperable due to collisions with space debris, leading to Kessler syndrome.
The question resolves NO if either of these conditions is not met.

P.title: Will Kessler syndrome occur before 2050?
P.body:
Resolution Criteria
This question will resolve as Yes if between 2018 to 2049 (inclusive), there is at least one calendar year when 10% or more of Earth's operational satellites become inoperable due to collisions with space debris

metadata.background_info:
The Kessler syndrome is a situation where a major satellite collision causes an increase in space junk, causing a cascading effect destroying many if not most other satellites.
As of 2018, we are losing about one satellite per year due to collisions with space junk, yet these collisions are far too small to cause a runaway effect. Furthermore, action has been taken by the Federal Communications Commission to reduce the chance of this happening and regulations in the US require all satellites launched after March 18, 2002 to be disposed of by controlled atmospheric reentry or a boost into a graveyard orbit after shutdown.

Q.title: Will there be a city on Earth with a population of over 100 million by 2100?
Q.body:
Resolution Criteria
For a mostly hairless, fangless species that was likely reduced to just a few thousand members in relatively recent times by a volcano, we've certainly been busy.
The human population on Earth now exceeds 7 billion. And we're still growing. Not everyone is thrilled by this. But it's reality.
Currently, as of Q2 2018, Tokyo, Japan is the world's largest metropolis, cramming over 38,000,000 people (give or take) into its borders.
But by the end of the century, we could (and probably will) witness far grander cities.
Per Canadian demographers, Daniel Hoornweg and Kevin Pope, for instance, Lagos in Nigeria may swell to 100+M by 2100 if trends continue. Face 2 Face Africa has the story:
By 2100 if Nigeria’s population continues to grow and people move to cities at the same rate as now, Lagos with its current 20 million people could be home to more people than the state of California.
The demographers' full paper is here.
The International Institute for Environment and Development goes into detail about why Hoornweg and Pope are so bullish on Africa here.
Whether it's Lagos that claims the crown or some other city in Africa or elsewhere, what do you think? Will some metro hit 100M people by 2100? (For the estimate we will include the general metropolitan area rather than the strict city boundaries, as done here)

reasons: The occurrence of Kessler syndrome, which involves a cascade of collisions between space debris, could have significant implications for global satellite communications and surveillance, potentially affecting global infrastructure and economies. This could indirectly influence urban development and the growth of mega-cities by impacting economic activities and technological advancements necessary for supporting large urban populations.

The growth of a city to over 100 million people would require substantial technological, economic, and infrastructural support, which could be compromised if a significant portion of satellite infrastructure is damaged or destroyed due to Kessler syndrome. This could affect everything from communication and transportation to disaster management and urban planning.
relevance.conclusion: Considering the potential indirect impacts of Kessler syndrome on global infrastructure and the subsequent effects on urban development, it is reasonable to explore the combined probability of these events occurring. The logical combination of these questions could provide insights into the interplay between space-based infrastructure and urban growth on a massive scale.

P.title: Will the Time person of the year in 2024 be the US president-elect?
P.body:
Resolution Criteria
This resolves positively if the Time person of the year in 2024 is the president-elect or both the president- and vice-president-elect, as determined by projected electoral votes as called by the Associated Press

Q.title: Will AI progress surprise us by predictions of AGI jumping sharply?
Q.body:
Resolution Criteria
What is the likelihood of discontinuous progress around the development of Human Level Machine Intelligence (i.e. machines that can accomplish a wide range of important tasks at least as good as human experts)?
This question resolves as YES if both the Metaculus prediction odds and the community prediction odds of a positive resolution to Human Machine Intelligence Parity by 2040 at least triple within any two-month period before its close date, and NO otherwise.
Some examples of a tripling of the odds are 60% becoming at least 81.8%, 70% becoming at least 87.5%, 80% becoming at least 92.3%, 90% becoming at least 96.4%, etc.
Fine Print
Edited 8/29/18 to require the change in both Metaculus and community prediction as the source of odds.

P_and_Q.title: Will the Time person of the year in 2024 be the US president-elect AND will AI progress surprise us by predictions of AGI jumping sharply?
P_and_Q.body:
This question resolves YES if both of the following occur: 
1. The Time person of the year in 2024 is the president-elect or both the president- and vice-president-elect, as determined by projected electoral votes as called by the Associated Press.
2. The Metaculus prediction odds and the community prediction odds of a positive resolution to Human Machine Intelligence Parity by 2040 at least triple within any two-month period before its close date. Examples of a tripling of the odds include 60% becoming at least 81.8%, 70% becoming at least 87.5%, 80% becoming at least 92.3%, 90% becoming at least 96.4%, etc. This change must occur in both Metaculus and community prediction odds.
Resolves NO otherwise.

Q_and_P.title: Will AI progress surprise us by predictions of AGI jumping sharply AND will the Time person of the year in 2024 be the US president-elect?
Q_and_P.body:
This question resolves YES if both of the following occur: 
1. The Metaculus prediction odds and the community prediction odds of a positive resolution to Human Machine Intelligence Parity by 2040 at least triple within any two-month period before its close date. Examples of a tripling of the odds include 60% becoming at least 81.8%, 70% becoming at least 87.5%, 80% becoming at least 92.3%, 90% becoming at least 96.4%, etc. This change must occur in both Metaculus and community predictions.
2. The Time person of the year in 2024 is the president-elect or both the president- and vice-president-elect, as determined by projected electoral votes as called by the Associated Press.
Resolves NO otherwise.

P.title: Will the Time person of the year in 2024 be the US president-elect?
P.body:
Resolution Criteria
This resolves positively if the Time person of the year in 2024 is the president-elect or both the president- and vice-president-elect, as determined by projected electoral votes as called by the Associated Press

metadata.background_info:
Every year, Time magazine publishes an issue with a person of the year, ostensibly the person with the greatest impact on the news of that year.
Since 2000, every Time person of the year on an election year was the president-elect; George Bush in 2000 and 2004, Barack Obama in 2008 and 2012, Donald Trump in 2016, and Joe Biden and Kamala Harris in 2020. Before then, the president-elect was also Time person of the year in 1992, 1980, 1976, 1964, 1948, and 1932.

Q.title: Will AI progress surprise us by predictions of AGI jumping sharply?
Q.body:
Resolution Criteria
What is the likelihood of discontinuous progress around the development of Human Level Machine Intelligence (i.e. machines that can accomplish a wide range of important tasks at least as good as human experts)?
This question resolves as YES if both the Metaculus prediction odds and the community prediction odds of a positive resolution to Human Machine Intelligence Parity by 2040 at least triple within any two-month period before its close date, and NO otherwise.
Some examples of a tripling of the odds are 60% becoming at least 81.8%, 70% becoming at least 87.5%, 80% becoming at least 92.3%, 90% becoming at least 96.4%, etc.
Fine Print
Edited 8/29/18 to require the change in both Metaculus and community prediction as the source of odds.

metadata.background_info:
Discontinuity in progress occurs when a particular technological advance pushes some progress metric substantially above what would be expected based on extrapolating past progress. If AI progress is unusually lumpy, i.e., arriving in unusually fewer larger packages rather than in the usual many smaller packages, then future progress might arrive faster than we would expect by simply looking at past progress. Moreover, if one AI team finds a big lump, it might jump way ahead of the other teams. According to AI Impacts, discontinuity on the path to AGI, lends itself to:
A party gaining decisive strategic advantage
A single important ‘deployment’ event
Other very sudden and surprising events

A previous question did a good job operationalising Human-machine intelligence parity. It proposes a generalised intelligence test that compares machine systems to human experts in each of physics, mathematics and computer science. Using this, we can define a surprising discontinuity in AI progress as a tripling of the odds (given by p/(1-p)) in both the Metaculus prediction and community prediction within a 2-month period.

reasons: The Time Person of the Year being the US president-elect could reflect a significant political event or shift that might also influence public and investor sentiments, potentially affecting technological investments and perceptions, including those in AI.

A sharp jump in predictions for AGI could be influenced by significant global or national events, including major political changes, which might be symbolized by the election of a new president, especially if they have a strong stance on technology and innovation.
relevance.conclusion: Considering the logical combination of these questions could provide insights into how political events and leadership changes might influence or correlate with technological advancements and perceptions in AI.

P.title: Will a practical nuclear fusion reactor first be developed in China?
P.body:
Resolution Criteria
For these purposes we define "practical" as an operational high-temperature nuclear fusion reactor that can (a) produce a demonstrated positive energy balance exceeding 100 megawatts for more than one week, and (b) have a sustainable plan for long-term operations (e.g. no critical hard-to-replace components that would be radiation-damaged to inoperability in a matter of days or weeks, etc.) These are chosen to roughly match this question.
This question will resolve as Yes if the first such reactor is built in China, and will resolve as No if the first such reactor is built anywhere else.
If no such reactor is built before January 1, 2050, this question will resolve as Ambiguous

Q.title: Will armed conflict between the Republic of China (Taiwan) and the People's Republic of China (PRC) cause at least 100 deaths before 2050?
Q.body:
Resolution Criteria
This question will resolve as Yes if, at any time between January 1, 2021 and January 1, 2050, either of the following occurs:
There are at least three credible government sources reporting at least one exchange of weapon fire between the national military forces or law enforcement personnel of Taiwan and the People's Republic of China causing a total of at least 100 deaths.
There are at least three credible news reports that at least one exchange of weapon fire between the national military forces or law enforcement personnel of the Republic of China (Taiwan) and the People's Republic of China causing a total of at least 100 deaths.
These 100 deaths do not have to occur in the same conflict or the same year; it is sufficient for multiple separate events to reach a total of 100 deaths in this period.
This question will resolve as No otherwise.
In the context of this question, an armed conflict will be defined as a dispute that concerns a government and/or territory where the use of armed force between two parties, of which at least one is the government of a state, results in an exchange of weapon fire or detonations

P_and_Q.title: Will a practical nuclear fusion reactor first be developed in China AND will armed conflict between the Republic of China (Taiwan) and the People's Republic of China (PRC) cause at least 100 deaths before 2050?
P_and_Q.body:
Resolution Criteria for the nuclear fusion reactor:
For these purposes we define "practical" as an operational high-temperature nuclear fusion reactor that can (a) produce a demonstrated positive energy balance exceeding 100 megawatts for more than one week, and (b) have a sustainable plan for long-term operations (e.g. no critical hard-to-replace components that would be radiation-damaged to inoperability in a matter of days or weeks, etc.) These are chosen to roughly match this question.
This question will resolve as Yes if the first such reactor is built in China, and will resolve as No if the first such reactor is built anywhere else.
If no such reactor is built before January 1, 2050, this question will resolve as Ambiguous.

Resolution Criteria for armed conflict:
This question will resolve as Yes if, at any time between January 1, 2021 and January 1, 2050, either of the following occurs:
There are at least three credible government sources reporting at least one exchange of weapon fire between the national military forces or law enforcement personnel of Taiwan and the People's Republic of China causing a total of at least 100 deaths.
There are at least three credible news reports that at least one exchange of weapon fire between the national military forces or law enforcement personnel of the Republic of China (Taiwan) and the People's Republic of China causing a total of at least 100 deaths.
These 100 deaths do not have to occur in the same conflict or the same year; it is sufficient for multiple separate events to reach a total of 100 deaths in this period.
This question will resolve as No otherwise.
In the context of this question, an armed conflict will be defined as a dispute that concerns a government and/or territory where the use of armed force between two parties, of which at least one is the government of a state, results in an exchange of weapon fire or detonations.

Q_and_P.title: Will armed conflict between Taiwan and the PRC cause at least 100 deaths before 2050 AND will a practical nuclear fusion reactor first be developed in China?
Q_and_P.body:
This question will resolve as YES if both of the following occur: 
1. At any time between January 1, 2021, and January 1, 2050, either of the following happens: 
a) There are at least three credible government sources reporting at least one exchange of weapon fire between the national military forces or law enforcement personnel of Taiwan and the People's Republic of China causing a total of at least 100 deaths. 
b) There are at least three credible news reports that at least one exchange of weapon fire between the national military forces or law enforcement personnel of the Republic of China (Taiwan) and the People's Republic of China causing a total of at least 100 deaths. These 100 deaths do not have to occur in the same conflict or the same year; it is sufficient for multiple separate events to reach a total of 100 deaths in this period. 
AND 
2. A practical nuclear fusion reactor is first developed in China, defined as an operational high-temperature nuclear fusion reactor that can (a) produce a demonstrated positive energy balance exceeding 100 megawatts for more than one week, and (b) have a sustainable plan for long-term operations. This question will resolve as NO if either of these conditions is not met. If no such reactor is built before January 1, 2050, this part of the question will resolve as Ambiguous.

P.title: Will a practical nuclear fusion reactor first be developed in China?
P.body:
Resolution Criteria
For these purposes we define "practical" as an operational high-temperature nuclear fusion reactor that can (a) produce a demonstrated positive energy balance exceeding 100 megawatts for more than one week, and (b) have a sustainable plan for long-term operations (e.g. no critical hard-to-replace components that would be radiation-damaged to inoperability in a matter of days or weeks, etc.) These are chosen to roughly match this question.
This question will resolve as Yes if the first such reactor is built in China, and will resolve as No if the first such reactor is built anywhere else.
If no such reactor is built before January 1, 2050, this question will resolve as Ambiguous

metadata.background_info: With an enormous amount of energy created per unit mass of fuel, cheap and abundance (e.g. deuterium) fuel, and relatively benign waste products, practical energy generation from nuclear fusion would be transformative for the world. A number of questions relate to efforts in the US and Europe, but there is another major player in the field: China. As discussed in this story, China is pouring significant resources into practical nuclear fusion.

Q.title: Will armed conflict between the Republic of China (Taiwan) and the People's Republic of China (PRC) cause at least 100 deaths before 2050?
Q.body:
Resolution Criteria
This question will resolve as Yes if, at any time between January 1, 2021 and January 1, 2050, either of the following occurs:
There are at least three credible government sources reporting at least one exchange of weapon fire between the national military forces or law enforcement personnel of Taiwan and the People's Republic of China causing a total of at least 100 deaths.
There are at least three credible news reports that at least one exchange of weapon fire between the national military forces or law enforcement personnel of the Republic of China (Taiwan) and the People's Republic of China causing a total of at least 100 deaths.
These 100 deaths do not have to occur in the same conflict or the same year; it is sufficient for multiple separate events to reach a total of 100 deaths in this period.
This question will resolve as No otherwise.
In the context of this question, an armed conflict will be defined as a dispute that concerns a government and/or territory where the use of armed force between two parties, of which at least one is the government of a state, results in an exchange of weapon fire or detonations

metadata.background_info: 2049 marks the 100th anniversary of the People's Republic of China. Graham Allison and The Brookings Institute have suggested that the PRC wants to achieve some form of national greatness by 2049, which would possibly include conquering Taiwan.

reasons: The development of a nuclear fusion reactor in China could be significantly impacted by geopolitical stability, including conflicts. If China is involved in a major conflict with Taiwan, it might redirect resources away from scientific and technological endeavors, including nuclear fusion projects, to military efforts.

A conflict could also lead to international sanctions or isolation, which might affect China's ability to collaborate internationally on technological projects such as nuclear fusion, potentially delaying or hindering its development.
Investors and stakeholders in nuclear fusion projects might view the geopolitical instability as a risk factor, affecting funding and support for such projects in China.
relevance.conclusion: Considering the potential impact of geopolitical stability on technological advancements, the logical combination of these questions is relevant as it explores how conflict might influence China's capability to achieve significant technological milestones like developing a practical nuclear fusion reactor.

P.title: Will retail and restaurant locations in the US decline by over 50% between 2020 and 2050?
P.body:
Resolution Criteria
This question resolves positively if, at any time between 2021 and 2050, at least 4 of the following 7 business categories report 50% fewer physical establishments than reported in 2020:
Electronics and appliance stores
Grocery stores
Health and personal care stores
Clothing stores
Shoe stores
Department stores
Limited-service restaurants
Resolution will be according to the US Bureau of Labor Statistics. The categories above are fully defined by NAICS in the fine print. If BLS no longer reports this data or changes their classification or methodology, Metaculus Admins may use a similar source of data or resolve ambiguously, at their discretion.
Fine Print
BLS categorizes businesses using NAICS. categories are listed with the total number of establishments in the US for 2020 (as of November 24, 2021). BLS series IDs are useful for retrieving data from here.
NAICS ID description 2020 number of establishments BLS series ID
4431 Electronics and appliance stores 43643 ENUUS0002054431
4451 Grocery stores 89545 ENUUS0002054451
4461 Health and personal care stores 112133 ENUUS0002054461
4481 Clothing stores 79968 ENUUS0002054481
4482 Shoe stores 15993 ENUUS0002054482
4522 Department stores 11567 ENUUS0002054522
722513 Limited-service restaurants 248416 ENUUS000205722513
Numbers of establishments in 2020 will be used as above, unless there is more accurate data known to Metaculus Admins.

Q.title: Will McDonald's be the first top global QSR to feature a cultivated meat product on their menu before 2027?
Q.body:
Resolution Criteria
This question will resolve as Yes if McDonald's is the first global Quick Service Restaurant to feature a cultivated meat product on their menu in any location before January 1, 2027. This question will resolve as No if no QSR offers cultivated meat by January 1, 2027, or another QSR offers cultivated meat before McDonald's.
For this question, "global Quick Service Restaurants" include:
McDonald's, Subway, KFC, Pizza Hut, Burger King, Domino’s, Hunt Brothers Pizza, Taco Bell, Wendy's, and Hardee's.
A restaurant is said to feature a cultivated meat product on its menu, if, in at least one location anywhere in the world that is open to the public, any member of the public is able to order the product, without requiring a reservation.
The product must be for sale, and free samples do not count. "Pop-up" restaurants that exist for a very short amount of time (such as those at a convention like CES) will not count toward resolution.
Any product and any meat may count for positive resolution (nuggets, patties, hotdogs, and so forth). The relevant meat substitute must contain at least 25% cultivated meat by weight

A restaurant is said to feature a cultivated meat product on its menu, if, in at least one location anywhere in the world that is open to the public, any member of the public is able to order the product, without requiring a reservation. The product must be for sale, and free samples do not count. "Pop-up" restaurants that exist for a very short amount of time (such as those at a convention like CES) will not count toward resolution. Any product and any meat may count for positive resolution (nuggets, patties, hotdogs, and so forth). The relevant meat substitute must contain at least 25% cultivated meat by weight. Resolves NO otherwise.

Q_and_P.body: Resolves YES if both of the following occur: (1) McDonald's is the first global Quick Service Restaurant to feature a cultivated meat product on their menu in any location before January 1, 2027. This includes McDonald's, Subway, KFC, Pizza Hut, Burger King, Domino’s, Hunt Brothers Pizza, Taco Bell, Wendy's, and Hardee's. metadata.background_info:
E-commerce has grown in popularity and has caused many to speculate that physical shopping may become obsolete in the future.
Physical department store locations have faced a slow decline in recent years, with a sharper decline exacerbated by the pandemic in 2020 (see the section titled "Number of department store locations in the US" here).
Neuroscientist and fiction author Erik Hoel wrote the following about physical retail in the year 2050 in a blog post published August 25, 2021
The majority of all current brick and mortar stores that are not located in scenic or tightly-packed downtowns will have closed. From stores that sell physical objects to chain restaurants, most of the physical locations you can go and shop will be gone. Instead, you will be able to get any product you would normally buy in a physical store delivered to you in under an hour, sometimes in mere minutes.

Q.title: Will McDonald's be the first top global QSR to feature a cultivated meat product on their menu before 2027?
Q.body:
Resolution Criteria
This question will resolve as Yes if McDonald's is the first global Quick Service Restaurant to feature a cultivated meat product on their menu in any location before January 1, 2027. This question will resolve as No if no QSR offers cultivated meat by January 1, 2027, or another QSR offers cultivated meat before McDonald's.
For this question, "global Quick Service Restaurants" include:
McDonald's, Subway, KFC, Pizza Hut, Burger King, Domino’s, Hunt Brothers Pizza, Taco Bell, Wendy's, and Hardee's.
A restaurant is said to feature a cultivated meat product on its menu, if, in at least one location anywhere in the world that is open to the public, any member of the public is able to order the product, without requiring a reservation.
The product must be for sale, and free samples do not count. "Pop-up" restaurants that exist for a very short amount of time (such as those at a convention like CES) will not count toward resolution.
Any product and any meat may count for positive resolution (nuggets, patties, hotdogs, and so forth). The relevant meat substitute must contain at least 25% cultivated meat by weight

metadata.background_info: Cultivated meat is animal meat that is produced by cultivating animal cells directly. Cultivated meat is made of the same cell types arranged in the same or similar structure as animal tissues, thus replicating the sensory and nutritional profiles of conventional meat. This production method eliminates the need to raise and farm animals for food.

reasons: The decline in physical retail and restaurant locations could influence the strategies of major QSRs like McDonald's, potentially accelerating their adoption of innovative products like cultivated meat to attract customers.

A significant reduction in physical locations might reflect broader shifts in consumer behavior and market conditions, which could be relevant for companies exploring new product offerings like cultivated meat.
relevance.conclusion: Considering the potential impact of a drastic change in the retail and restaurant landscape on the strategies of major QSRs, it is reasonable to explore the logical combination of these two forecasting questions.

P.title: Will the USA enter a second civil war before 2031?
P.body:
Resolution Criteria
This question will resolve as Yes if all of the following conditions are met before January 1, 2031:
The Insurrection Act is invoked.
While the Insurrection Act is invoked, there are at least 500 deaths in a 6 month period as a result of armed conflicts between US residents and a branch of the US military, national guard, or in conflicts between/among such branches.
All of these deaths occur in any US state(s) (including DC).
Fine Print
Any conflicts between the US military and the armed forces of another country will be excluded from consideration in this question. Conflicts between the US military and US residents, possibly supported by other nations with weapons or resources, will be included.
Conflicts between civilians and local police will not be included, unless there are active armed forces in the region providing mutual support.
Deaths are calculated among all of the states (and Washington, DC) in the United States. New states which are admitted shall be included, states which secede or are removed, will not be included. Suicides do not count towards the death count.

Q.title: Will smoking and sex be less prevalent in the United States in 2050 than in 2021?
Q.body:
Resolution Criteria
This question will resolve as Yes if any credible surveys of US adults in the year 2050 report that the share of adults who have smoked in the past week and the share of adults who have had sex in the past week were both lower than in the year 2021. Comparisons between 2050 and 2021 must be of similar methodology (see fine print) to count towards resolution. If no comparable surveys can be found for both smoking and sex by the resolution date of December 31, 2054, this question will resolve as Ambiguous. This question will resolve as Yes if any credible surveys would result in positive resolution, conflicting surveys will be considered irrelevant.
Fine Print
Regarding similar methodology, if a survey in 2021 includes e-cigarettes and a survey from 2050 does not the surveys would not be considered to have similar methodology. However, different methodologies can still be acceptable if it can be logically deduced that the surveys provide evidence toward resolution. For example, if a survey in 2021 asked whether respondents had sex in the past year and 25% answered no, and a survey in 2050 asked if respondents had sex in the past five years and 40% answered no, it can be deduced that a larger share of adults in 2050 had not had sex in the past year than in 2021 because the five year period would include the past year.

P_and_Q.title: Will the USA enter a second civil war before 2031 AND will smoking and sex be less prevalent in the United States in 2050 than in 2021?
P_and_Q.body:
Resolves YES if both of the following conditions are met: 
1. The USA enters a second civil war before January 1, 2031, under these specific conditions: 
   - The Insurrection Act is invoked. 
   - While the Insurrection Act is invoked, there are at least 500 deaths in a 6 month period as a result of armed conflicts between US residents and a branch of the US military, national guard, or in conflicts between/among such branches. 
   - All of these deaths occur in any US state(s) (including DC). 
   - Conflicts between the US military and the armed forces of another country are excluded. Conflicts between civilians and local police are not included unless there are active armed forces in the region providing mutual support. Deaths are calculated among all of the states (and Washington, DC) in the United States. New states which are admitted shall be included, states which secede or are removed, will not be included. Suicides do not count towards the death count.
2. Any credible surveys of US adults in the year 2050 report that the share of adults who have smoked in the past week and the share of adults who have had sex in the past week were both lower than in the year 2021. Comparisons between 2050 and 2021 must be of similar methodology to count towards resolution. If no comparable surveys can be found for both smoking and sex by the resolution date of December 31, 2054, this question will resolve as Ambiguous. 
Resolves NO otherwise.

Q_and_P.title: Will smoking and sex be less prevalent in the United States in 2050 than in 2021 AND will the USA enter a second civil war before 2031?
Q_and_P.body:
Resolution Criteria for both events:
1. Smoking and sex prevalence: This question will resolve as Yes if any credible surveys of US adults in the year 2050 report that the share of adults who have smoked in the past week and the share of adults who have had sex in the past week were both lower than in the year 2021. Comparisons between 2050 and 2021 must be of similar methodology to count towards resolution. If no comparable surveys can be found for both smoking and sex by the resolution date of December 31, 2054, this question will resolve as Ambiguous. This question will resolve as Yes if any credible surveys would result in positive resolution, conflicting surveys will be considered irrelevant.

2. USA entering a second civil war: This question will resolve as Yes if all of the following conditions are met before January 1, 2031: The Insurrection Act is invoked; While the Insurrection Act is invoked, there are at least 500 deaths in a 6 month period as a result of armed conflicts between US residents and a branch of the US military, national guard, or in conflicts between/among such branches; All of these deaths occur in any US state(s) (including DC).

This question will resolve as YES only if both conditions are met. It will resolve as NO if either condition is not met.

Fine Print

metadata.background_info: Although democracies are generally unlikely to enter civil war (see this list of civil wars for a rough overview), the United States faces a particularly unusual situation at the moment. The current COVID-19 pandemic, social protests, effects of social media platform manipulation, and the presidential election all have the potential to disrupt social cohesion and garner negative attitudes toward the government. See this related question for a shorter timeframe: Will the USA enter a second civil war before July 2021?

Q.title: Will smoking and sex be less prevalent in the United States in 2050 than in 2021?
Q.body:
Resolution Criteria
This question will resolve as Yes if any credible surveys of US adults in the year 2050 report that the share of adults who have smoked in the past week and the share of adults who have had sex in the past week were both lower than in the year 2021. Comparisons between 2050 and 2021 must be of similar methodology (see fine print) to count towards resolution. If no comparable surveys can be found for both smoking and sex by the resolution date of December 31, 2054, this question will resolve as Ambiguous. This question will resolve as Yes if any credible surveys would result in positive resolution, conflicting surveys will be considered irrelevant.
Fine Print
Regarding similar methodology, if a survey in 2021 includes e-cigarettes and a survey from 2050 does not the surveys would not be considered to have similar methodology. However, different methodologies can still be acceptable if it can be logically deduced that the surveys provide evidence toward resolution. For example, if a survey in 2021 asked whether respondents had sex in the past year and 25% answered no, and a survey in 2050 asked if respondents had sex in the past five years and 40% answered no, it can be deduced that a larger share of adults in 2050 had not had sex in the past year than in 2021 because the five year period would include the past year.

metadata.background_info:
Neuroscientist and fiction author Erik Hoel wrote the following about social behavior in the year 2050 in a blog post published August 25, 2021
All socially risky behavior is on the decline, and has been in the decade since social media and the introduction of the smart phone. People in 2050 will have less sex, do less drugs, have less affairs, smoke less, and conform more in their opinions.
A survey from Gallup finds that 16% of US adults had smoked a cigarette in the last week in 2021. And an article in the Washington Post reports that 23% of US adults had not had sex in the past year in 2018.

reasons: The potential occurrence of a second civil war in the USA could lead to significant societal and demographic changes, impacting behaviors such as smoking and sexual activity. A civil war could disrupt social norms, health services, and population dynamics, potentially influencing the prevalence of these behaviors by 2050.

Exploring the combined probability of these events could provide insights into the long-term societal impacts of severe national conflicts, offering a comprehensive view of how such a conflict might reshape societal behaviors over decades.
relevance.conclusion: Considering the potential long-term societal impacts of a second civil war, it is reasonable to explore how such a conflict might influence behaviors like smoking and sexual activity by 2050. The logical combination of these questions could provide valuable insights into the broader consequences of national conflicts on societal norms and health behaviors.

P.title: Will China's GDP exceed the United States' GDP in any year before 2041?
P.body:
Resolution Criteria
This question will resolve as Yes if China's nominal GDP for a given year exceeds US nominal GDP (for that year) before 2041. For the purpose of this question, we refer to data published by the World Bank.
Fine Print
For the purpose of this question, nominal GDP will be compared after converting China's nominal GDP to USD (using exchanges rates that are commonly used by the World Bank for this purpose).
Previously, the resolution criteria was confusing, so this has been changed. It is reproduced here for reference:
This question resolves positive if China's GDP exceeds that of the United States in any 1 year before (and including) 2040. For the purpose of this question, we refer to data published by the World Bank that are adjusted for historical domestic prices.

Q.title: Will there be a non-BJP Prime Minister of India before 2030?
Q.body:
Resolution Criteria
This question will resolve positive if before 2031-01-01, an Indian Prime Minister takes office who is not a member of the BJP, or if the acting Prime Minister changes membership to another party.
Fine Print
[EIDT] Sylvain 2021-09-02: reversed the title, which was the opposite of the resolution criteria.

P_and_Q.title: Will China's GDP exceed the United States' GDP in any year before 2041 AND will there be a non-BJP Prime Minister of India before 2030?
P_and_Q.body:
Resolution Criteria
This question will resolve as YES if both of the following conditions are met: a.) China's nominal GDP for a given year exceeds US nominal GDP (for that year) before 2041, based on data published by the World Bank and using exchange rates commonly used by the World Bank for converting China's GDP to USD. b.) Before 2031-01-01, an Indian Prime Minister takes office who is not a member of the BJP, or if the acting Prime Minister changes membership to another party.
Fine Print
For the GDP comparison, nominal GDP will be compared after converting China's nominal GDP to USD. For the Indian Prime Minister condition, the resolution criteria refer to the political affiliation of the Prime Minister.

Q_and_P.title: Will there be a non-BJP Prime Minister of India before 2030 AND will China's GDP exceed the United States' GDP in any year before 2041?
Q_and_P.body:

China's nominal GDP for a given year exceeds US nominal GDP (for that year) before 2041, referring to data published by the World Bank and using exchange rates commonly used by the World Bank for this purpose.

For the Indian Prime Minister part, [EIDT] Sylvain 2021-09-02: reversed the title, which was the opposite of the resolution criteria. It is reproduced here for reference: This question resolves positive if China's GDP exceeds that of the United States in any 1 year before (and including) 2040. For the purpose of this question, we refer to data published by the World Bank that are adjusted for historical domestic prices.

P.title: Will China's GDP exceed the United States' GDP in any year before 2041?
P.body:
Resolution Criteria
This question will resolve as Yes if China's nominal GDP for a given year exceeds US nominal GDP (for that year) before 2041. For the purpose of this question, we refer to data published by the World Bank.
Fine Print
For the purpose of this question, nominal GDP will be compared after converting China's nominal GDP to USD (using exchanges rates that are commonly used by the World Bank for this purpose).
Previously, the resolution criteria was confusing, so this has been changed. It is reproduced here for reference:
This question resolves positive if China's GDP exceeds that of the United States in any 1 year before (and including) 2040. For the purpose of this question, we refer to data published by the World Bank that are adjusted for historical domestic prices.

metadata.background_info:
China is today one of the major economies in the world. It ranks second in terms of gross domestic product and it contributes about 36 percent to world growth. Due to the size of its economy, Chinese business cycle fluctuations potentially affect economies worldwide. The Chinese economy further has substantial effects on global poverty, global trade, climate change, and much else.
From the late 1970s, China saw an annual average growth rate of 9.9 per cent for more than three decades. This followed the introduction of reform and opening-up policies in 1978. In recent years, however, growth has slowed, to only 6.9 per cent in 2015. In Angus Maddison's book, The Outlook for China and the World Economy, he forecasts that China's GDP will surpass that of the United States in the first half of this century, and likely as soon as 2030.
China has seen an average of 9.8% GDP growth since the 1970s, far higher than the 2.8% average observed in the United States in the same period. Despite the recent slowdown in Chinese growth, its rates of Total Factor Productivity has been growing on average at twice the average rate in the United States (around 3% in China vs around 1.5% in the United States). Similarly, Chinese capital formation rates have tended to be almost twice capital formation rates in the United States.

Q.title: Will there be a non-BJP Prime Minister of India before 2030?
Q.body:
Resolution Criteria
This question will resolve positive if before 2031-01-01, an Indian Prime Minister takes office who is not a member of the BJP, or if the acting Prime Minister changes membership to another party.
Fine Print
[EIDT] Sylvain 2021-09-02: reversed the title, which was the opposite of the resolution criteria.

metadata.background_info: Prime Minister Modi of India is a member of the BJP. The BJP won a majority of 282 seats in India's Lok Sabha in 2014 and increase that majority to 303 seats in 2019, outperforming expectations.

reasons: The economic and political shifts in two major Asian countries could have broader implications for regional stability, trade, and global geopolitics. Analysts might be interested in understanding how changes in economic leadership in China relative to the U.S. could interact with political shifts in India, potentially affecting bilateral relations, regional alliances, or economic policies.

Investors or policymakers might be interested in these combined probabilities to assess risks and opportunities in the region, considering how economic power shifts and political changes could influence market conditions and foreign policy strategies.
relevance.conclusion: While the direct connection between these two events is not strong, the broader geopolitical and economic implications make the combination of these questions relevant for certain analytical purposes.

P.title: Will there be a "World War Three" before 2050?
P.body:
Resolution Criteria
This question will resolve as Yes if, at any time between January 1, 2019 and January 1, 2050, both of these conditions are true:
There is a military conflict involving countries representing in totality at least 30% of world GDP in PPP or 50% of world population in any year in which the conflict is ongoing.
At least 10 million people (civillians or military personnel) have been killed in the conflict.
[see edit history in the fine print]
Fine Print
PPP will may be determined from the following sources, in order of precedence:
IMF
World Bank
United Nations
CIA

metadata.background_info:
World War I was a global war originating in Europe that lasted from 28 July 1914 to 11 November 1918. One of the deadliest conflicts in history, an estimated 9 million combatants and 7 million civilians died as a direct result of the war.
World War II was a global war that lasted from 1939 to 1945. A state of total war emerged, directly involving more than 100 million people from over 30 countries. World War II was the deadliest conflict in human history, marked by 50 to 85 million fatalities, most of whom were civilians in the Soviet Union and China. It included massacres, the genocide of the Holocaust, strategic bombing, premeditated death from starvation and disease, and the only use of nuclear weapons in war.
World War III is the name given to a hypothetical third worldwide large-scale military conflict subsequent to World War I and World War II. The term has been in use since at least as early as 1941. Some have applied it loosely to refer to limited or smaller conflicts such as the Cold War or the War on Terror, while others have operated under the assumption that such a conflict would surpass both prior world wars in both the level of its widespread scope and of its overall destructive impact.
As of January 2019, World War III does not appear to have started - but there have been a number of historical close calls that are widely regarded as having been narrowly-missed possible catalysts of such a conflict.
In 1949, after the unleashing of nuclear weaponry at the end of WWII, physicist Albert Einstein suggested that any outcome of a possible WWIII would be so dire as to revert mankind back to the Stone Age. When asked by journalist Alfred Werner what types of weapons Einstein believed World War III might be fought with, Einstein warned, "I know not with what weapons World War III will be fought, but World War IV will be fought with sticks and stones". It can be inferred here that Einstein assumed that World War III would either exterminate, or else nearly exterminate the human race, presumably due to nuclear warfare.

Q.title: Will PsiQuantum have a commercial quantum computer by 2025?
Q.body:
Resolution Criteria
This question will resolve positively via PsiQuantum company report that they have a quantum computer for sale by 2025

metadata.background_info:
In early 2021, the firm PsiQuantum announced that they plan on having a commercial quantum computer by 2025. The PsiQuantum computer, named "the Q-1", uses a 'photon qubit' approach as opposed to a 'matter qubit'. According to PsiQuantum,
There are many ways to make small numbers of qubits, but only one way to scale beyond 1,000,000 qubits and deliver an error corrected, fault tolerant general purpose quantum computer – and that is photonics.
Today, after numerous breakthroughs and advances in quantum architecture and silicon photonics, we uniquely have a clear path to building a useful quantum computer.
In 2020, PsiQuantum completed Series C funding of $150M bringing their total funding to $215M. Their list of investors includes BlackRock, Microsoft's Venture Fund, and Founders Fund.

reasons: The occurrence of a major global conflict like World War Three could drastically affect global technological development and economic stability, potentially impacting the progress of companies like PsiQuantum in developing quantum computing technologies.

In a scenario of global conflict, resources might be redirected towards defense and away from technological innovation, which could delay PsiQuantum's ability to develop or commercialize a quantum computer by 2025.
relevance.conclusion: Considering the potential impact of a global conflict on technological and economic landscapes, it is reasonable to explore the logical combination of these two questions.

P.title: If there's a nuclear conflict involving >1,000 detonations, will humanity be extinct within 50 years?
P.body:
Resolution Criteria
This question resolves positively if the human population falls to zero within 50 years of the final detonation as part of the first nuclear conflict (between January 1, 2021 and January 1, 2100) which involves >1,000 offensive nuclear detonations. For simplicity, we will consider detonations to be part of the same nuclear conflict if each detonation occurs within 30 days of another detonation (regardless of who detonates the weapons, who their targets are, what their motivations are, etc.).
This question resolves ambiguously if there is no nuclear conflict involving >1000 detonations by January 1, 2100.
For the purposes of this question, "humans" are members of a species most of whose members could at some point in their lives reproduce with typical 2021 humans without medical assistance (even if young or old members of the species could not do so or a minority of members of the species could never do so). In scenarios where this question would resolve positively given that definition, but there remain beings that at least one 2021 Metaculus moderator would consider "human" (possible examples: some human-like digital minds; some possible types of genetically altered humans), this question will instead resolve ambiguously. This is because it is debatable whether such scenarios should count as "extinction".
Fine Print
This question can resolve positively even if the nuclear conflict wasn't the sole cause, a major cause, or even a contributing factor in the eventual extinction event. (This is because it would be useful for this question to capture instances in which the nuclear conflict merely contributed to rather than solely or directly causing extinction, but it seems hard to capture that neatly except via this more expansive resolution criteria.)

Q.title: Will Saudi Arabia normalize relations with Israel by 2031 if Iran gets a nuclear bomb by then?
Q.body:
Resolution Criteria
If the Iran nuke question resolves positively (i.e. the Iranian Regime credibly states it has a nuclear weapon or a weapon test, as judged by media reports), then this question will resolve positively if at least five reliable media outlets report that the State of Israel is legally recognized by the Kingdom of Saudi Arabia before 2031-01-01, and negatively otherwise. Recognition is generally considered valid if it is declared by law, or declared through a large international body such as the United Nations. If the Iran nuke question resolves negatively or ambiguously, this question resolves ambiguously

P_and_Q.title: If there's a nuclear conflict involving >1,000 detonations, will humanity be extinct within 50 years AND will Saudi Arabia normalize relations with Israel by 2031 if Iran gets a nuclear bomb by then?
P_and_Q.body:
Resolution Criteria for combined question:
1. The first part of this question resolves positively if the human population falls to zero within 50 years of the final detonation as part of the first nuclear conflict (between January 1, 2021 and January 1, 2100) which involves >1,000 offensive nuclear detonations. For simplicity, we will consider detonations to be part of the same nuclear conflict if each detonation occurs within 30 days of another detonation (regardless of who detonates the weapons, who their targets are, what their motivations are, etc.). This question resolves ambiguously if there is no nuclear conflict involving >1000 detonations by January 1, 2100.
2. The second part of this question resolves positively if the Iran nuke question resolves positively (i.e., the Iranian Regime credibly states it has a nuclear weapon or a weapon test, as judged by media reports), and at least five reliable media outlets report that the State of Israel is legally recognized by the Kingdom of Saudi Arabia before 2031-01-01. It resolves negatively otherwise. Recognition is generally considered valid if it is declared by law, or declared through a large international body such as the United Nations. If the Iran nuke question resolves negatively or ambiguously, this question resolves ambiguously.

This combined question resolves YES only if both parts resolve positively. It resolves NO if either part resolves negatively or ambiguously.

Q_and_P.title: Will Saudi Arabia normalize relations with Israel by 2031 if Iran gets a nuclear bomb by then, AND will humanity be extinct within 50 years if there's a nuclear conflict involving >1,000 detonations?
Q_and_P.body:
Resolution Criteria for Saudi Arabia and Israel: If the Iran nuke question resolves positively (i.e., the Iranian Regime credibly states it has a nuclear weapon or a weapon test, as judged by media reports), then this question will resolve positively if at least five reliable media outlets report that the State of Israel is legally recognized by the Kingdom of Saudi Arabia before 2031-01-01, and negatively otherwise. Recognition is generally considered valid if it is declared by law, or declared through a large international body such as the United Nations. If the Iran nuke question resolves negatively or ambiguously, this question resolves ambiguously.

Resolution Criteria for Humanity Extinction: This question resolves positively if the human population falls to zero within 50 years of the final detonation as part of the first nuclear conflict (between January 1, 2021 and January 1, 2100) which involves >1,000 offensive nuclear detonations. For simplicity, we will consider detonations to be part of the same nuclear conflict if each detonation occurs within 30 days of another detonation (regardless of who detonates the weapons, who their targets are, what their motivations are, etc.). This question resolves ambiguously if there is no nuclear conflict involving >1000 detonations by January 1, 2100. For the purposes of this question, "humans" are members of a species most of whose members could at some point in their lives reproduce with typical 2021 humans without medical assistance (even if young or old members of the species could not do so or a minority of members of the species could never do so). In scenarios where this question would resolve positively given that definition, but there remain beings that at least one 2021 Metaculus moderator would consider "human" (possible examples: some human-like digital minds; some possible types of genetically altered humans), this question will instead resolve ambiguously. This is because it is debatable whether such scenarios should count as "extinction".

This combined question resolves YES only if both conditions are met: Saudi Arabia recognizes Israel by 2031 if Iran gets a nuclear bomb, AND humanity goes extinct within 50 years following a nuclear conflict involving >1,000 detonations. It resolves NO if either condition fails, and resolves ambiguously if either individual question resolves ambiguously.

Q.title: Will Saudi Arabia normalize relations with Israel by 2031 if Iran gets a nuclear bomb by then?
Q.body:
Resolution Criteria
If the Iran nuke question resolves positively (i.e. the Iranian Regime credibly states it has a nuclear weapon or a weapon test, as judged by media reports), then this question will resolve positively if at least five reliable media outlets report that the State of Israel is legally recognized by the Kingdom of Saudi Arabia before 2031-01-01, and negatively otherwise. Recognition is generally considered valid if it is declared by law, or declared through a large international body such as the United Nations. If the Iran nuke question resolves negatively or ambiguously, this question resolves ambiguously

metadata.background_info: In 2020, Israel normalized relations with the United Arab Emirates, Bahrain, and Morocco in the Abraham Accords. This comes in the face of increasing cooperation between the United States, Israel, and the Gulf countries who all face a threat from Iran and have expressed concern about Iran's nuclear program. A previous question asked if Saudi Arabia would normalize relations with Israel in 2021.

reasons: The potential for a nuclear conflict involving over 1,000 detonations could drastically alter global political dynamics, potentially affecting international relations, including those between Saudi Arabia and Israel. In such a scenario, the priorities and alliances of nations could shift significantly, possibly influencing Saudi Arabia's decision to normalize relations with Israel.

The aftermath of a large-scale nuclear conflict might lead to a reevaluation of security and diplomatic strategies by many countries, including Saudi Arabia, which could either hasten or delay normalization with Israel depending on the perceived threats and opportunities in a post-conflict world.
relevance.conclusion: Considering the potential global impact of a large-scale nuclear conflict, it is reasonable to explore how such an event might influence specific international relations, such as those between Saudi Arabia and Israel. The logical combination of these questions could provide insights into how extreme global events might affect diplomatic decisions.

P.title: Will China recognize the sovereignty of Taiwan by 2050?
P.body:
Resolution Criteria
This question will resolve as Yes if, at any time between January 1, 2020 to January 1 2050, The People's Republic of China formally and publicly recognizes the Sovereignty of the Republic of China (Taiwan)

Q.title: Will there be an AI Sputnik moment before 2050?
Q.body:
Resolution Criteria
There is said to be an "AI Sputnik moment" if ANY of the following come true before 2050,
A major technology company (>50 billion dollar market cap, in 2021 US dollars, right before the announcement) announces the creation of an AI system. Upon the announcement, their stock price skyrockets by over 100% compared to its previous value within 7 days, and numerous highly credible media reports claim that this rise in stock price is likely a result of the AI development.
News of an AI development triggers the head of government of the top 2 nations by GDP nominal to give a public speech regarding the ramifications of this particular AI development, within two weeks of the initial news reports.
The Nasdaq Composite (which is currently heavily weighted towards companies in the information technology sector) rises over 30% in the course of a single week, and numerous highly credible media reports claim that this rise in stock prices is likely a result of the AI development.
The Google Trends monitor for artificial intelligence shows that interest in artificial intelligence rises by over 100% relative to of its previous value, compared to the week prior (using the resolution at 12 months, as currently displayed by the Google Trends widget). If Google Trends changes their functionality or methodology dramatically (as determined by Metaculus admins), then this condition can no longer trigger a positive resolution.
Practically all reliable media outlets are referring to an AI development as an AI Sputnik moment, as referring to the historical Sputnik 1 satellite
Fine Print
Google Trends index scores vary depending on the date and location from which a user checks the site. To reduce ambiguity, to trigger the Google Trends section of the resolution criteria:
At least two Metaculus administrators need to be able to see the >100% Google Trends increase, when checking from different locations.
The increase must remain >100% for at least four days to trigger a Yes resolution. For instance, if we first notice an increase of >100% on a Monday, we will check again on Friday. We will only resolve "Yes" if the reported increase for the weeks in question is >100% on both days we check, for both admins, and we have no evidence that it dropped below 100% at any point during those four days.

P_and_Q.title: Will China recognize the sovereignty of Taiwan AND will there be an AI Sputnik moment before 2050?
P_and_Q.body:
Resolves YES if both of the following occur: 

1. The People's Republic of China formally and publicly recognizes the sovereignty of the Republic of China (Taiwan) at any time between January 1, 2020, and January 1, 2050.

2. An AI Sputnik moment occurs before 2050, defined by any of the following criteria:
   - A major technology company (>50 billion dollar market cap, in 2021 US dollars, right before the announcement) announces the creation of an AI system, causing their stock price to skyrocket by over 100% within 7 days, with numerous credible media reports attributing this rise to the AI development.
   - News of an AI development prompts the head of government of the top 2 nations by GDP nominal to give a public speech about the AI's ramifications within two weeks of the initial reports.
   - The Nasdaq Composite rises over 30% in a single week, with numerous credible media reports attributing this rise to the AI development.
   - Google Trends shows a >100% increase in interest in artificial intelligence relative to the previous week, remaining elevated for at least four days as confirmed by at least two Metaculus administrators from different locations.

Resolves NO otherwise.

Q_and_P.title: Will there be an AI Sputnik moment before 2050 AND will China recognize the sovereignty of Taiwan by 2050?
Q_and_P.body:
Resolves YES if both of the following occur: 
1. There is an "AI Sputnik moment" before 2050, defined by ANY of the following criteria: 
a) A major technology company (>50 billion dollar market cap, in 2021 US dollars, right before the announcement) announces the creation of an AI system, causing their stock price to skyrocket by over 100% within 7 days, with numerous highly credible media reports attributing this rise to the AI development. 
b) News of an AI development prompts the head of government of the top 2 nations by GDP nominal to give a public speech about the ramifications of this AI development within two weeks of the initial news. 
c) The Nasdaq Composite rises over 30% in a week, with numerous highly credible media reports linking this rise to the AI development. 
d) Google Trends shows a >100% increase in interest in artificial intelligence relative to the previous week, which must be confirmed by at least two Metaculus administrators from different locations and remain >100% for at least four consecutive days. 
2. The People's Republic of China formally and publicly recognizes the sovereignty of the Republic of China (Taiwan) any time between January 1, 2020, and January 1, 2050. 
Resolves NO otherwise.

P.title: Will China recognize the sovereignty of Taiwan by 2050?
P.body:
Resolution Criteria
This question will resolve as Yes if, at any time between January 1, 2020 to January 1 2050, The People's Republic of China formally and publicly recognizes the Sovereignty of the Republic of China (Taiwan)

Q.body:
Resolution Criteria
