reasons: The emergence of a major new donor in the Effective Altruist space could increase funding and attention to various causes, including aging research. If such a donor prioritizes longevity or related fields, this could accelerate significant developments in aging research.
A significant development in aging research could attract more philanthropic interest from the Effective Altruist community, potentially influencing the decisions of major donors.
relevance.conclusion: Considering the potential interplay between major philanthropic movements and breakthroughs in specific research areas, it is reasonable to explore the logical combination of these two forecasting questions.

P.title: Will synthetic biological weapons infect 100 people by 2030?
P.body:
Resolution Criteria
This question will resolve as Yes if a credible medical source announces at least 100 people are confirmed "infected" by one or more confirmed synthetic "biological weapon"s and that this has occured before 2030. The consequences of infection may or may not be immediately harmful. An agent can even be latent, or cause a delayed onset of disease, as long as the agent is still present and functional 24 hrs after infection (as opposed to being destroyed by the immune system). But if it causes some definite, confirmed harmful effect, and then self-destructs before 24 hrs have passed, that would still count. The infection can result from a terrorist attack, attack on enemy military personnel, an experiment, accident, with the infected persons' consent, or from any other cause

Q.title: Will a legacy automaker go bankrupt before 2030?
Q.body:
Resolution Criteria
If one of the top 10 current automakers (by vehicle sales), including Volkswagen, Toyota, Daimler/Mercedes, Ford, General Motors, Hyundai, Honda, SAIC, BMW, and Nissan, declares bankruptcy, the question resolves positively. Otherwise, it resolves negatively.
Fine Print
If the automaker declares bankruptcy the question will resolve positively even if they are bought out by another company or given a loan by the government

P_and_Q.title: Will synthetic biological weapons infect 100 people AND a legacy automaker go bankrupt before 2030?
P_and_Q.body:
Resolution Criteria
This question will resolve as YES if both of the following occur before 2030: 
1. A credible medical source announces at least 100 people are confirmed "infected" by one or more confirmed synthetic "biological weapon"s. The consequences of infection may or may not be immediately harmful. An agent can even be latent, or cause a delayed onset of disease, as long as the agent is still present and functional 24 hrs after infection. However, if it causes some definite, confirmed harmful effect, and then self-destructs before 24 hrs have passed, that would still count. The infection can result from a terrorist attack, attack on enemy military personnel, an experiment, accident, with the infected persons' consent, or from any other cause.
2. One of the top 10 current automakers (by vehicle sales), including Volkswagen, Toyota, Daimler/Mercedes, Ford, General Motors, Hyundai, Honda, SAIC, BMW, and Nissan, declares bankruptcy. The resolution will be positive even if the bankrupt automaker is bought out by another company or given a loan by the government.
Resolves NO otherwise.

Q_and_P.title: Will a legacy automaker go bankrupt before 2030 AND will synthetic biological weapons infect 100 people by 2030?
Q_and_P.body: Resolves YES if both of the following occur: a.) One of the top 10 current automakers (by vehicle sales), including Volkswagen, Toyota, Daimler/Mercedes, Ford, General Motors, Hyundai, Honda, SAIC, BMW, and Nissan, declares bankruptcy before 2030. This resolution applies even if the automaker is bought out by another company or given a loan by the government. AND b.) A credible medical source announces at least 100 people are confirmed "infected" by one or more confirmed synthetic "biological weapon"s before 2030. The consequences of infection may or may not be immediately harmful. An agent can even be latent, or cause a delayed onset of disease, as long as the agent is still present and functional 24 hrs after infection. The infection can result from various causes including a terrorist attack, attack on enemy military personnel, an experiment, accident, or with the infected persons' consent. Resolves NO otherwise.

P.title: Will synthetic biological weapons infect 100 people by 2030?
P.body:
Resolution Criteria
This question will resolve as Yes if a credible medical source announces at least 100 people are confirmed "infected" by one or more confirmed synthetic "biological weapon"s and that this has occured before 2030. The consequences of infection may or may not be immediately harmful. An agent can even be latent, or cause a delayed onset of disease, as long as the agent is still present and functional 24 hrs after infection (as opposed to being destroyed by the immune system). But if it causes some definite, confirmed harmful effect, and then self-destructs before 24 hrs have passed, that would still count. The infection can result from a terrorist attack, attack on enemy military personnel, an experiment, accident, with the infected persons' consent, or from any other cause

metadata.background_info:
A synthetic biological weapon is a 'living' agent capable of infecting, harming, and/or killing a target host. For the purposes of this question, we focus on human hosts, exclude weapons that consist only of toxins, even if their source is biological: synthetic or otherwise. Nor does it include something like a genetically engineered mosquito carrying natural unmodified malaria. 'Living' means it must either be self-reproducing, like a bacteria or parasite, or like a virus, capable of hijacking a host cell to produce new copies of itself. A synthetic biological agent may be a 'natural' disease causing organism that has at least been genetically engineered (and not merely selectively bred); an entirely new kind of organism, virus, or similar created from scratch; or anything in between those extremes.
If the agent is based on an existing disease causing organism, there must be confirmation that the symptoms of infection by the disease causing agent(s) are confirmed by a credible medical source to be different than those of the original, or alternatively that the infectious 'behavior', or capabilities of the agent are confirmed different than the original. This is to exclude infections that are medically indistuingishable from the natural version, which might make cases too difficult to verify.
The consequences of infection must be undesireable - ie, not something that could concievably be offered as a product for improving the health of a customer, to improve athletic or cognitive abilities, for recreational use, or any other purpose desireable to those infected. It must be confirmed to be at least capable of adversely impacting the victims' physical or mental health, making them smell in a way that attracts trained dogs, causing them to develop an addiction to some brand of fast food, or some other undesireable effect.

Q.title: Will a legacy automaker go bankrupt before 2030?
Q.body:
Resolution Criteria
If one of the top 10 current automakers (by vehicle sales), including Volkswagen, Toyota, Daimler/Mercedes, Ford, General Motors, Hyundai, Honda, SAIC, BMW, and Nissan, declares bankruptcy, the question resolves positively. Otherwise, it resolves negatively.
Fine Print
If the automaker declares bankruptcy the question will resolve positively even if they are bought out by another company or given a loan by the government

metadata.background_info:
As EV technology becomes more widely adopted, and as dates are set for the prohibition of sales of new internal combustion engine (ICE) vehicles in some places, the question arises: will legacy automakers be nimble enough to adapt to the market landscape?
Automakers can expect to incur R&D costs associated with battery technology, in addition to the necessary overhaul of current factories. For example, Volkswagen is spending billions in their efforts to expand their EV offerings, and Mercedes is also mapping out a future centrally focused on EV's.
For some additional context, here is the IEA Historical EV Market Share and Outlook.

reasons: The potential outbreak of a synthetic biological weapon could lead to widespread panic and economic instability, which might negatively impact the automotive industry, including leading automakers. This could increase the likelihood of bankruptcy for vulnerable companies.

In a scenario where a major automaker goes bankrupt, economic ripple effects could exacerbate national security concerns, potentially making the country more susceptible to biological attacks or less capable of responding effectively.
relevance.conclusion: Considering the logical combination of these two questions could provide insights into how major crises in public health and economic sectors might interact and influence each other.

P.title: Will retail and restaurant locations in the US decline by over 50% between 2020 and 2050?
P.body:
Resolution Criteria
This question resolves positively if, at any time between 2021 and 2050, at least 4 of the following 7 business categories report 50% fewer physical establishments than reported in 2020:
Electronics and appliance stores
Grocery stores
Health and personal care stores
Clothing stores
Shoe stores
Department stores
Limited-service restaurants
Resolution will be according to the US Bureau of Labor Statistics. The categories above are fully defined by NAICS in the fine print. If BLS no longer reports this data or changes their classification or methodology, Metaculus Admins may use a similar source of data or resolve ambiguously, at their discretion.
Fine Print
BLS categorizes businesses using NAICS. categories are listed with the total number of establishments in the US for 2020 (as of November 24, 2021). BLS series IDs are useful for retrieving data from here.
NAICS ID description 2020 number of establishments BLS series ID
4431 Electronics and appliance stores 43643 ENUUS0002054431
4451 Grocery stores 89545 ENUUS0002054451
4461 Health and personal care stores 112133 ENUUS0002054461
4481 Clothing stores 79968 ENUUS0002054481
4482 Shoe stores 15993 ENUUS0002054482
4522 Department stores 11567 ENUUS0002054522
722513 Limited-service restaurants 248416 ENUUS000205722513
Numbers of establishments in 2020 will be used as above, unless there is more accurate data known to Metaculus Admins.

Q.title: If human-level artificial intelligence is developed, will World GDP grow by at least 30.0% in any of the subsequent 15 years?
Q.body:
Resolution Criteria
If a machine passes the test in this Metaculus question, this question resolves as YES if world GDP grows by at least 30.0% for any single year in the fifteen years following the date of the test, according to a reputable organization such as The World Bank, and NO if it doesn't.
If no machine passes that test by 2100-01-01, then this question resolves ambiguously.

P_and_Q.title: Will retail and restaurant locations in the US decline by over 50% between 2020 and 2050 AND if human-level artificial intelligence is developed, will World GDP grow by at least 30.0% in any of the subsequent 15 years?
P_and_Q.body:
Resolution Criteria for the first part: This question resolves positively if, at any time between 2021 and 2050, at least 4 of the following 7 business categories report 50% fewer physical establishments than reported in 2020: Electronics and appliance stores, Grocery stores, Health and personal care stores, Clothing stores, Shoe stores, Department stores, Limited-service restaurants. Resolution will be according to the US Bureau of Labor Statistics. The categories above are fully defined by NAICS in the fine print. If BLS no longer reports this data or changes their classification or methodology, Metaculus Admins may use a similar source of data or resolve ambiguously, at their discretion.

Resolution Criteria for the second part: If a machine passes the test in this Metaculus question, this question resolves as YES if world GDP grows by at least 30.0% for any single year in the fifteen years following the date of the test, according to a reputable organization such as The World Bank, and NO if it doesn't. If no machine passes that test by 2100-01-01, then this question resolves ambiguously.

This question resolves YES only if both parts resolve YES according to their respective criteria. Resolves NO otherwise.

Q_and_P.title: If human-level artificial intelligence is developed, will World GDP grow by at least 30.0% in any of the subsequent 15 years AND will retail and restaurant locations in the US decline by over 50% between 2020 and 2050?
Q_and_P.body:
Resolution Criteria for combined question:

1. If a machine passes the test in the Metaculus question related to human-level artificial intelligence, this combined question resolves as YES if BOTH of the following occur:
a) World GDP grows by at least 30.0% for any single year in the fifteen years following the date of the test, according to a reputable organization such as The World Bank.
b) At any time between 2021 and 2050, at least 4 of the following 7 business categories report 50% fewer physical establishments than reported in 2020: Electronics and appliance stores, Grocery stores, Health and personal care stores, Clothing stores, Shoe stores, Department stores, Limited-service restaurants. Resolution will be according to the US Bureau of Labor Statistics.

If no machine passes that test by 2100-01-01, then this question resolves ambiguously.

If BLS no longer reports this data or changes their classification or methodology, Metaculus Admins may use a similar source of data or resolve ambiguously, at their discretion.

Resolution Criteria
This question resolves positively if, at any time between 2021 and 2050, at least 4 of the following 7 business categories report 50% fewer physical establishments than reported in 2020:
Electronics and appliance stores
Grocery stores
Health and personal care stores

Department stores
Limited-service restaurants
Resolution will be according to the US Bureau of Labor Statistics. The categories above are fully defined by NAICS in the fine print. 4431 Electronics and appliance stores 43643 ENUUS0002054431

metadata.background_info:
E-commerce has grown in popularity and has caused many to speculate that physical shopping may become obsolete in the future.
Physical department store locations have faced a slow decline in recent years, with a sharper decline exacerbated by the pandemic in 2020 (see the section titled "Number of department store locations in the US" here).
Neuroscientist and fiction author Erik Hoel wrote the following about physical retail in the year 2050 in a blog post published August 25, 2021
The majority of all current brick and mortar stores that are not located in scenic or tightly-packed downtowns will have closed. From stores that sell physical objects to chain restaurants, most of the physical locations you can go and shop will be gone. Instead, you will be able to get any product you would normally buy in a physical store delivered to you in under an hour, sometimes in mere minutes.

Q.title: If human-level artificial intelligence is developed, will World GDP grow by at least 30.0% in any of the subsequent 15 years?
Q.body:
Resolution Criteria
If a machine passes the test in this Metaculus question, this question resolves as YES if world GDP grows by at least 30.0% for any single year in the fifteen years following the date of the test, according to a reputable organization such as The World Bank, and NO if it doesn't.
If no machine passes that test by 2100-01-01, then this question resolves ambiguously.

metadata.background_info:
In economist Robin Hanson's 2001 paper Economic Growth Given Machine Intelligence, he writes
A simple exogenous growth model gives conservative estimates of the economic implications of machine intelligence. [...] Without machine intelligence, world product grows at a familiar rate of 4.3% per year, doubling every 16 years, with about 40% of technological progress coming from ordinary computers. With machine intelligence, the (instantaneous) annual growth rate would be 45%, ten times higher, making world product double every 18 months! If the product shares are raised by 20%, and general technology growth is lowered to preserve the 4.4% figure, the new doubling time falls to less than 6 months.

reasons: The decline in physical retail and restaurant locations could be influenced by technological advancements, including the development of human-level AI, which might lead to increased online commerce and automation in service industries.
The economic impact of human-level AI could be significant, potentially leading to changes in consumer behavior and business models that affect physical retail spaces.
relevance.conclusion: Considering the potential interplay between technological advancements and economic structures, it is reasonable to explore how the development of human-level AI might correlate with changes in physical retail and restaurant locations.

P.title: Will any country that had nuclear weapons on July 1, 2017 give them up before 2035?
P.body:
Resolution Criteria
This question will resolve as Yes if one of the 9 nations known to possess nuclear weapons on July 1, 2017 (U.S., China, Russia, U.K., France, Israel, India, Pakistan, or North Korea) is certified by the International Atomic Energy Agency to have dismantled all nuclear devices and signs the 2017 UN ban on nuclear weapons on or before January 1, 2035.
Fine Print
For the purposes of this question, in the case of territorial disputes or challenges to a government's legitimacy, successor governments will be recognized as those which hold over 50% of the nation's de facto controlled territory on July 1, 2017. The successor government must also hold a political capital city within that same territory. If any of the 9 countries no longer exist or have no succesor as defined by January 1, 2035, they will be ignored for the resolution of the question.

Q.title: If one or more HEMP attacks occur by 2030, will that lead to >10 million fatalities?
Q.body:
Resolution Criteria
This question will resolve as Yes if at least one High-altitude Electromagnetic Pulse attack occurs before January 1, 2030 and the total fatalities caused by all HEMP attacks by January 1, 2030 is above 10 million, according to at least 3 estimates from credible sources by January 31, 2030. Fatalities from all HEMP attacks in this time period will be counted towards positive resolution, even if they are from separate countries and separate conflicts.
The question resolves negatively if at least one HEMP attack occurs by 2030 but there aren't at least 3 credible sources which estimate the total fatalities caused to be above 10 million.
The question resolves ambiguously if no HEMP attack occurs by 2030, or if fewer than 3 credible sources provide any estimates about the number of fatalities from HEMP attacks by 2030.
For this question, a HEMP is defined as either:
a >1 kiloton explosion at greater than 30 kilometer altitude (including detonation in space), or
a non-nuclear device which produces similar or larger EMP field levels over similar or larger areas compared to a HEMP detonation
Fine Print
No attempt will be made to second-guess credible sources regarding what fatalities should be considered "caused" by the HEMP attack(s). This could include fatalities caused by the initial blast of a HEMP attack, the radioactive fallout, or by the infrastructure disruption caused by the HEMP. But estimates of fatalities caused by other bombs or military strikes in the same time place will not be counted as estimates of fatalities caused by the HEMP attack(s).
HEMPs for testing purposes will not count as HEMP attacks, even if they cause significant damage would not count towards positive resolution. "HEMPs for testing purposes" are defined as HEMPs which are claimed as being a test by an official government communication within 30 days of the event, without this being disputed by reliable media, state reports, or multinational reports.

P_and_Q.title: Will any country that had nuclear weapons on July 1, 2017 give them up before 2035 AND if one or more HEMP attacks occur by 2030, will that lead to >10 million fatalities?
P_and_Q.body: Resolves YES if both of the following occur: (1) One of the 9 nations known to possess nuclear weapons on July 1, 2017 (U.S., China, Russia, U.K., France, Israel, India, Pakistan, or North Korea) is certified by the International Atomic Energy Agency to have dismantled all nuclear devices and signs the 2017 UN ban on nuclear weapons on or before January 1, 2035. For the purposes of this question, in the case of territorial disputes or challenges to a government's legitimacy, successor governments will be recognized as those which hold over 50% of the nation's de facto controlled territory on July 1, 2017. The successor government must also hold a political capital city within that same territory. If any of the 9 countries no longer exist or have no successor as defined by January 1, 2035, they will be ignored for the resolution of the question. (2) At least one High-altitude Electromagnetic Pulse attack occurs before January 1, 2030 and the total fatalities caused by all HEMP attacks by January 1, 2030 is above 10 million, according to at least 3 estimates from credible sources by January 31, 2030. Fatalities from all HEMP attacks in this time period will be counted towards positive resolution, even if they are from separate countries and separate conflicts. The question resolves negatively if at least one HEMP attack occurs by 2030 but there aren't at least 3 credible sources which estimate the total fatalities caused to be above 10 million. The question resolves ambiguously if no HEMP attack occurs by 2030, or if fewer than 3 credible sources provide any estimates about the number of fatalities from HEMP attacks by 2030. For this question, a HEMP is defined as either: a >1 kiloton explosion at greater than 30 kilometer altitude (including detonation in space), or a non-nuclear device which produces similar or larger EMP field levels over similar or larger areas compared to a HEMP detonation. HEMPs for testing purposes will not count as HEMP attacks, even if they cause significant damage would not count towards positive resolution. "HEMPs for testing purposes" are defined as HEMPs which are claimed as being a test by an official government communication within 30 days of the event, without this being disputed by reliable media, state reports, or multinational reports.

Q_and_P.title: Will one or more HEMP attacks lead to >10 million fatalities by 2030 AND will any nuclear-armed country give up its nuclear weapons by 2035?
Q_and_P.body:
This question will resolve as YES if both of the following conditions are met: 
1. At least one High-altitude Electromagnetic Pulse (HEMP) attack occurs before January 1, 2030, and the total fatalities caused by all HEMP attacks by January 1, 2030 is above 10 million, according to at least 3 estimates from credible sources by January 31, 2030. Fatalities from all HEMP attacks in this time period will be counted towards positive resolution, even if they are from separate countries and separate conflicts. The question resolves negatively if at least one HEMP attack occurs by 2030 but there aren't at least 3 credible sources which estimate the total fatalities caused to be above 10 million. The question resolves ambiguously if no HEMP attack occurs by 2030, or if fewer than 3 credible sources provide any estimates about the number of fatalities from HEMP attacks by 2030.
2. One of the 9 nations known to possess nuclear weapons on July 1, 2017 (U.S., China, Russia, U.K., France, Israel, India, Pakistan, or North Korea) is certified by the International Atomic Energy Agency to have dismantled all nuclear devices and signs the 2017 UN ban on nuclear weapons on or before January 1, 2035.
Resolves NO otherwise.

P.title: Will any country that had nuclear weapons on July 1, 2017 give them up before 2035?
P.body:
Resolution Criteria
This question will resolve as Yes if one of the 9 nations known to possess nuclear weapons on July 1, 2017 (U.S., China, Russia, U.K., France, Israel, India, Pakistan, or North Korea) is certified by the International Atomic Energy Agency to have dismantled all nuclear devices and signs the 2017 UN ban on nuclear weapons on or before January 1, 2035.
Fine Print
For the purposes of this question, in the case of territorial disputes or challenges to a government's legitimacy, successor governments will be recognized as those which hold over 50% of the nation's de facto controlled territory on July 1, 2017. The successor government must also hold a political capital city within that same territory. If any of the 9 countries no longer exist or have no succesor as defined by January 1, 2035, they will be ignored for the resolution of the question.

metadata.background_info:
In July 2017, 122 member states of the United Nations adopted a ban on nuclear weapons. The participating states agreed to "never under any circumstances to develop, test, produce, manufacture, otherwise acquire, possess or stockpile nuclear weapons or other nuclear explosive devices."
Notably, none of the nations that currently possess nuclear weapons participated in the negotiations of the ban or adopted the document.
Several treaties prior to this aimed to curb the development of nuclear weapons, notably the 1968 Non-Proliferation Treaty (NPT), which sought to limit nuclear development beyond five nuclear powers - the U.S., Russia, China, the U.K., and France.
Arguments against nuclear disarmament typically cite the principle of deterrence, that the possession of nuclear weapons by some states precludes the development or use of weapons by other states, due to the threat of nuclear retaliation. Proponents of the ban argue that previous efforts have not prevented states such as North Korea from pursuing nuclear programs, and that disarmament, rather than deterrence, is the best way to prevent nuclear war.
It's not unprecedented for states to completely disarm, however. South Africa dismantled its nuclear weapons beginning in 1989 and joined the NPT as a non-nuclear state. Three former Soviet republics, previously part of a nuclear-capable nation, also joined the NPT as non-nuclear states.

Q.title: If one or more HEMP attacks occur by 2030, will that lead to >10 million fatalities?
Q.body:
Resolution Criteria
This question will resolve as Yes if at least one High-altitude Electromagnetic Pulse attack occurs before January 1, 2030 and the total fatalities caused by all HEMP attacks by January 1, 2030 is above 10 million, according to at least 3 estimates from credible sources by January 31, 2030. Fatalities from all HEMP attacks in this time period will be counted towards positive resolution, even if they are from separate countries and separate conflicts.
The question resolves negatively if at least one HEMP attack occurs by 2030 but there aren't at least 3 credible sources which estimate the total fatalities caused to be above 10 million.
The question resolves ambiguously if no HEMP attack occurs by 2030, or if fewer than 3 credible sources provide any estimates about the number of fatalities from HEMP attacks by 2030.
For this question, a HEMP is defined as either:
a >1 kiloton explosion at greater than 30 kilometer altitude (including detonation in space), or
a non-nuclear device which produces similar or larger EMP field levels over similar or larger areas compared to a HEMP detonation
Fine Print
No attempt will be made to second-guess credible sources regarding what fatalities should be considered "caused" by the HEMP attack(s). This could include fatalities caused by the initial blast of a HEMP attack, the radioactive fallout, or by the infrastructure disruption caused by the HEMP. But estimates of fatalities caused by other bombs or military strikes in the same time place will not be counted as estimates of fatalities caused by the HEMP attack(s).
HEMPs for testing purposes will not count as HEMP attacks, even if they cause significant damage would not count towards positive resolution. "HEMPs for testing purposes" are defined as HEMPs which are claimed as being a test by an official government communication within 30 days of the event, without this being disputed by reliable media, state reports, or multinational reports.

metadata.background_info:
According to the US EMP Commission (2004):
"Several potential adversaries have or can acquire the capability to attack the United States with a high-altitude nuclear weapon-generated electromagnetic pulse (EMP). [...] EMP is one of a small number of threats that can hold our society at risk of catastrophic consequences. EMP will cover the wide geographic region within line of sight to the nuclear weapon. It has the capability to produce significant damage to critical infrastructures and thus to the very fabric of US society, as well as to the ability of the United States and Western nations to project influence and military power."
Other questions in this tournament asks how likely a HEMP attack is by 2024 and how many such attacks would occur if at least one does (link will be added soon). This question is about how much harm would occur if one or more HEMP attacks occur. For further context on this question, see Nuclear risk research idea: Nuclear EMPs and [rough notes] Harms from nuclear conflict via EMPs, fallout, or ozone depletion.

reasons: The logical combination of these questions might be considered by those interested in global security and the potential escalation of conflicts involving nuclear and non-nuclear weapons. If a country gives up its nuclear arsenal, it might impact the likelihood or severity of HEMP attacks, especially if these attacks are seen as alternative strategies by other nations.
Exploring this combination could help in understanding the broader implications of disarmament on global stability and the risks associated with other forms of mass destruction.
relevance.conclusion: While the direct connection between nuclear disarmament and the occurrence and impact of HEMP attacks might not be straightforward, the combination could provide insights into global security dynamics and the interplay between different forms of weaponry and their geopolitical implications.
